div.l: (base) My tale is doon we been almoost at towne
(base) Hic finita fabula Summonitoris

Et Incipit Prologus Cleria
Oxonie cuius fabula est de
Grisilde mitissima

Sir clerk of Oxenforde
Oure oost saide.

Ye ride as coy and stille
as a maide.

Were newe spoused / sitting
at the bord.
This day ne herd I of your tonge a worde
I trowe ye studie aboute som sophim
But Salomon seith eueri thing hath tyme
For goddes sake as beth of better chere
It is no tyme for to studie hiere
Telle vs som meri tale by your fey
For what man that is entred in a play
He nedes must vn to the play assente
But precheth nat as freres don in lente
To make vs for oure olde sinnes wepe
Ne that thi tale make vs nat to slepe
Tell vs som meri thing of auentures
Your termes your colours and your figures
Kepe hem in stoor til so be that ye endite
High stile and whan that men to kinges write
Speketh so plain at this tyme we you preye
That we may vnderstonde what ye say
This worthi clerk benigly ansuerde
Oost quod he I am vndre your yerde
Ye haue of vs as now the gouernaunce
And therfor wol I do you obeissaunce
As fer as reson asketh verrily
I wol you a tale wich that I
Lerned at Padow of a worthi clerk
As preued be his wordes and his werk
He is now ded and nailed in his cheste
I pray to god so yeue his soule good reste
Fraunceis Petrak the laureat Poete
Hiȝt this clerk whos Rethorik swete
Enlumined al Itaille of Poetrie
As Lynian did of Philosophie
Or lawe or othir art particuler
But deth that wol nat suffren vs duellen here
But as it were a twinkling of an yhe
Hem bothe hath slain and al shal we dye
But forth for to tellen of this worthi man
That tauȝt me this tale as I began
I sey that first stile he enditeth
Or he the dite of his tale writeth
A probleme in wich discrieth he
Pemond and of Saluces the contre
And spekith of Appenyn the hilles highe
That ben the boundes of westlumbardie
And of mount Vesulus ine special
Where that the Poo out of a welle smal
Takith his first springing ⁊ his sours
That estward ay encresith in his cours
To Emelieward to Ferare and Venise
The wich a long thing were to deuise
And truly as to my iugement
Me thinketh it is a thing inpartinent
Saue that he wol conueye his matere
But this is his tale wich that ye may hiere

Hic desinit Prologus Clerici Oxonie
Et Incipit Fabula euisdem.
There is at the west side of Itail
Doun at the roote of Vesulus the colde.
A lusti plain habundant of vitail
Where many a tour ⁊ toun thou maist beholde
That founded were in tyme of faders olde
And many anothir delectable siȝt
And Saluces this noble contre hiȝt
A Markas whilom lord was of that londe
As were his worthi elders him before
And obeisaunt ay redi to his honde
Were al his hertes bothe lesse and more
Thus in delite he lyued and hath don yore
Beloued and drad throuȝ fauour of fortune
Bothe of his lordes and of his comune
There with he was to speke of his linage
The gentillest born of Lumbardie
A fair persone and strong and yong of age
And full of honour and curtesie
Discrete Inouȝ his contre for to giue
Saue in som thinges that he was to blame
And Walter was this yong lordes name
I blame him thus that he considered nouȝt
In tyme coming what miȝt hym betide
But on his lust present was al his thouȝt
As for to hauke and hunte on eueri side
Wel ny al othir cures let he slide
And he nolde and that was werst of al
Wedde no wif for nouȝt that may befal
Onli that point his people bar so sore
That flok mel on a day they to him went
And oon of hem that wisest was of lore
Or ellis that the lord wolde best assent
That he shulde telle him what his people ment
For ellis coude he shewe wel such mater
He to the Markꝭes seid as ye shal hiere
O noble Markas your humanite
Assureth vs and yeueth vs hardinesse
As ofte as tyme is of necessite
That we to you mow telle oure heuinesse
Accepteth lord now of your gentilnesse
That if we with pitous hert vnto you pleine
And lat your eres nat my vois disdeine
Al haue I nat to don in this matere
More than an othir man hath in this place
Yit for as moch as ye my lord so dere
Han alwey shewid me fauour and grace
I dare the better aske of you a space
Of audience to shewen oure request
And ye my lord to don riȝt as you lest
For certes Lord so wel vs liketh you
And al your werkes and euer han dōmn that we
Ne coude nat vs self deuisen hou
We miȝt lyuen in more felicite
Saue oo thing lord if it your will be
That for to be a wedded man you lest
Than were your people in souerain hertes rest
Boweth your nek vnder that blisful yok
Of soueranite nouȝt of seruise
Wich that men clepe spousail or wedlok
And thinketh lorde among your thouȝtes wise
Hou that oure daies passe in sondri wise
For thouȝ we slepe or wake or renne or ride
Ay fleeth the tyme it nil noman abide
And thouȝ youre grene youthe floure as yit
In crepith age alwey as stille as stoon
And deth manaseth eueri age and smit
In ech estat for ther escapith non
And also certein and we knowe echon
That we shal dye as vncertein we al
Ben on that day whan deth shal on vs falle
Accepteth than of vs the true entent
That neuer yit re fusedest thin hest
And we wol lorde if that ye wol assent
Chese you a wif in short tyme ate lest
Born of the gentillest and of the mest
Of al this lond so that it ouȝt seme
Honour to god and you as we can deme
Deliuer vs out of al this besi drede
And take a wif for high goddes sake
For if so befel as god forbede
That throuȝ your deth your lyne shulde slake
And that a straunge successour shuld take
Your heritage oo woo were vs on lyue
Wherfore we pray you hasteli to wyue.
Her meke praier and her pitous chere
Made the Markas hert to haue pite
Ye wol quod he myn ougne people dere
To that I thouȝt neuer erst streine me
I me reioisshed of my liberte
That selde tyme is founde in mariage
There I was fre I mot be in seruage
But natheles I se your true entent
And trust vpon your wit and haue don ay
Wherfore of my fre wil I wyl assent
To wedde me as sone as euer I may
But there as ye han profered me to day
To chese me a wif I you relese
That chois and pray you of that profre cese
For god it wot that children ofte ben
Vnlik her worthi elders hem before
Bounte comth al of god nat of the stren
Of wich thei ben ygendred and ybore
I trust in goddes bounte and therfore
Myn mariage and myn estat and reste
I him betake he may do as him lest
Lat me alone in chesing of my wif
That charge on my bak I wol endure
But I you charge vp on peine of your lif
What wif that I take ye me ass ure
To worship hir whil that hir lyf may dure
In worde and werke bothe hiere ⁊ eueri where
As she an Emperours douȝter were
And furthermore thus shal ye swere that ye
Ageins my chois shal neuer grucche ne striue
For sith I shal forgo my liberte
At your request as euer mot I thriue
There as myn hert is set there wol I wyue
And but ye wol assente in such maner
I pray you spekith nomore of this mater
With hertly will they sweren and assenten
To al this thing there said no wiȝt nay
Beseching him of grace or that they wenten
That he wolde graunt hem a certain day
Of his spousaill as sone as euer he may
For yit alwey the people som what dredde
Lest that the Markas no wif wolde wedde
He graunted hem a day such as him lest
On wich he wolde be wedded sikerli
And seid he did al this at here request
And they with humble entent buxomly
Knelyng vpon her knees ful reuerently
Him thanking al and thus they han an ende
Of her entent and hom agein they wende
And hereupon he took his officers
And comaundeth for the feste to purueye
And to his priue kniȝtes and squiers
Such charge yaf as he list on hem leye
And they to his comaundement obeye
And ech of hem doth his diligence
To don vnto the feste reuerence
Nouȝt fer from thilk paleis honourable
There as this Markas shope his mariage
There stood a throop of siȝt delectable
In wich that poure folk of that village
Hadden her bestes and her herbergage
And of her labour took her sustenaunce
Aftir that the erthe yaf hem habundaunce
Among these poore folk there duelt a man
Wich þtat was holden for poorest of hem alle
But the high god somtime sende can
His grace in to a litel Oxes stalle
Ianicula men of that throop him calle
A douȝter faire I nouȝ to siȝt
And Grisildis this yong maiden hiȝt
For to speke of vertuous beaute
Than was she oon the fairest vnder sonne
For poorli I fostred vp was she
No licorous lust was thruȝ hir herte yronne
Wel ofter of the welle than of the tonne
She drank and for she wold veru plese
She knewe wel labour but non idel ese
But thouȝ this maide tender were of age
Yit in the brest of hir virginite
Ther was enclosed ripe and sad corage
And in gret reuerence and charite
Hir olde poore fader fostred she
A fewe sheep spinning on the felde she kepte
She nolde nat ben idel til she slepte
And whan she homward cam she wolde bringe
Wortes or othir herbes tymes ofte
The wiich she shred and sethed for her lyuing
And made hire bed ful harde ⁊ no thing softe
And ay she kept hir faders lif on lofte
With eueri obeissaunce ⁊ diligence
That childe may do to faders reuerence
Vpon Grisilde this poore creature
Ful ofte sithis this Markas set his yhe
As he on hunting rod parauenture
And whan it fel that he miȝt her espie
He nouȝt with wantoun loking of folie
His yhen cast on hir but in sad wise
Vpon hir chere he wolde him ofte avise
Commending in his hert hir wommanhed
And eke her vertu passing any wiȝt
Of so yong age as wel in chere and dede
For thouȝ the people had no gret insiȝt
In vertu he considerid ful riȝt
Hir bounte and dispose that he wolde
Wedde hir onli if euer he wedde shulde
The day of wedding cam but no wiȝt can
Telle what womman it shulde be
For wich merueil wondred many a man
And seide whan they were in priuete
Wil nat oure lord leue yit his vanite
Wol he nat wedde allas the while
Whi wol he thus him self and vs beguile
But natheles this Markas hath don make
Of gemmes set in golde and in asure
Broches and ringes for Grisildes sake
And of hir clothing took he the mesure
Of a maide lik to hir stature
And eke of othir ornamentez alle
That vnto such a wedding shuld falle
The tyme of vndern of the same day
Approcheth that this wedding shuld be
And al the paleis put was in array
Bothe halle and chambres ech in his degre
Houses of office stuffed with plente
Ther maist thou se of deintevous vitail
That may be founde as fer as lasteth Itail
This roiall Markas richeli arraied
Lordes and Ladyes in his company
The wich that to the feste were praid
And of his retenue the bachillery
With many a soun of diuers melodie
Vn to the village of wich I tolde
In this array the riȝt wey they holde
Grisilde of this god wot ful innocent
That for hir shapen was al this array
To fecche water at a welle is went
And comth hom as sone as euer she may
For wel she herd sey that ilke day
The Markas shuld wedde and if she miȝt
She wolde fain haue sene som of that siȝt
She thoȝt I wol with othir maidens stonde
That ben my felawes in oure dore and se
The Markesesse / and therfor wol I fonde
To do at hom as sone as it may be
The labour wich that longeth vnto me
And that I may at leiser hir beholde
If she this wey vnto the castel wolde
And as she wold ouer the thresshholde gon
The Markas cam and gan hir for to calle
And she set doun hir water pot anon
Beside the thresshold in an oxes stalle
And doun vpon hir knees she gan to falle
And with sad contenaunce kneled stille
Til she had herd the lordes wille
This thouȝtful Markas spak vnto this maide
Ful soberli and said in this manere
Where is youre fader O. Grisildes he seide
And she with reuerence ⁊ humble chere
Ansuerd lord he is al redi hiere
And in she goth withoute lenger let
And to the Markas she hir fader fet
He bi the hand than took the olde man
And seide thus whan he had him aside
Ianicula I ne may ne can
Lenger the plesaunce of myn hert hide
If thou vouche saf what so betide
Thi douȝter wol I take or that I wende
As for my wif vnto her lyues ende
Thou louest me I wot it wel certein
And art my feithful liege man yborn
And al that liketh me I dar wel sein
It liketh the and specialli therfore
Telle me that point that I haue seid before
And if thou wolt vnto that purpos drawe
To take me as for thi sone in lawe
The sodein caas the man astonied so
That red he wax abasshed and al quaking
He stood . vnnethes seide he wordes moo
But onli thus lord quod he my willing
Is as ye wil ne ayenst youre liking
I wol no thing. ye be my lord so dere
Right as you list gouerneth this matere
Yit wyl I quod this Markas softely
That in thi chambre I thou and she
Haue a collacion and woest now whi
For I wil aske if it hir wil be
To be my wif and reule hir aftir me
And al this shal be don in thi presence
I wol nat speke out of thin audience
And in the chambre whil they were aboute
Her tretise wich as ye shal aftir hiere
The people cam in to the hous withoute
And wondred hem hou in honest manere
And tentifly she kepte hir fader dere
But vtterli Grisilde wonder miȝt
For neuer erst ne saw she such a siȝt
Mo wonder is thouȝ she were astonied
To se so gret a gest come in that place
She neuer was to such gestes woned
For wich she loked with ful face pale
But shortli forth this mater for to chace
These ar the wordes that the Markas saide
To this benigne verri feithful maide
Grisilde he seide ye shul wel vnderstonde
It liketh to your fader and to me
That I you wedde and eke it may so stonde
As I suppose ye wol that it so be
But these demaundes aske I first quod he
That sith it shal be don in hasti wise
Wol ye assente or ellis you auise
I sey this be ye redi with good herte
To al my lust and that I freli may
As me best thinketh to do you laugh or smert
And neuer ye it to grucche niȝt nor day
And whan I sey ye / ye sey nat nay
Neither be worde ne frouning contenaunce
Swere this and hiere I swere oure alliaunce
Wondring vpon this thing quaking for drede
She seide lord vndigne or vnworthi
I am to that honour that ye me bid
But as ye wol your self riȝt so wol I
And hiere I swere that neuer willingly
In werk ne thouȝt I wol you disobeie
For to be ded thouȝ me were loth to deye
This is Inouȝ Grisilde myn quod he
And forth he goth with a ful sobre chere
Out at the dore / and after that cam she
And to the people he seid in this manere
This is my wif quod he that stondith hiere
Honoureth hir and loueth hir I pray
Who so me loueth ther is nomore to sey
And for that no thing of hir olde gere
She wolde bringe vnto his hous he bad
That wommen shuld dispoilen hir riȝt there
Of wich these ladyes were nat riȝt glad
To handle hir clothes wherin she was clad
But natheles this maide briȝt of hewe
From foot to hed they clothed han al newe
Her heres they kempt that lay vntressed
Ful rudeli with her fingres smale
A croune on hir hed they han I dressed
And set it ful of ouches grete ⁊ smale
Of hir array what shuld I make a tale
Vnnethe the people hir knewe for hir fairnesse
Whan she translated was in such richesse
This Markas hath hire spoused with a ring
Brouȝt for the same cause and than hir set
Vpon an hors snow white ⁊ wel ambling
And to his paleis or he lenger let
With ioyful people that hir lad ⁊ met
Conueied hir and thus the day they spende
In reuel. til the sonne gan descende
And shortli forth this tale for to chace
I sey that to this newe Markesesse
God hath such fauour sent hir of his grace
That it ne semed be any liklinesse
That she was born and fed in rudenesse
As in a cite or in an oxes stalle
But norisshed in an Emperours halle
To eueri wiȝt she wexe is so dere
And worshipful that folk that she was bore
And from hir birthe knewe hir yere be yere
Vnnethe trouthed they but durst haue swore
That to Ianicule of wich I spak before
She douȝter were for as by coniecture
Hem thouȝt she was an othir creature
For thouȝ that euer vertuous was she
She was encreced in such excellence
Of thewes gode in high bounte
And so discrete / and faire of eloquence
So benigne and so digne of reuerence
And coude so the people hertes embrace
That ech hir loued that loked in hir face
Nat onli of Saluces in the toun
Publisshed was the beaute of hir name
But eke beside in many a region
If oon seide wel an othir seid the same
So spread of hir highe bounte the fame
That men ⁊ women as wel yong as olde
Gon to Saluces vpon hir to beholde
Thus Walter louh nat but roially
Wedded with fortunat honeste
In goddes pees lyueth ful esily
At hom and outward grace I nouȝ had he
And for he saugh that vnder lowe degre
Was of vertu hid / the people him helde
A prudent man / and that is sene ful selde
Nat onli this Grisilde throuȝ her wit
Coude al the fet of wifly humblenesse
But eke whan that the cas required it
The comon profit coude redresse
There nas discord rancour ne heuinesse
In al that lond that she ne coude appese
And wisely bringe hem in rest and ese
Thouȝ her husbond absent were or non
If gentilmen or othir of the cuntre
Were wroth / she wolde bringe hem at oon
So wise and ripe wordes had she
And iugementes of so gret equite
That she from heuen sent was as men wende
People to saue and eueri wrong to amende
Nouȝt long time aftir this Grisilde
Was wedded she a douȝter hath ybore
Al had hir leuer haue born a knaue childe
Glad was the Markis and the folk therfore
She may vn to a knaue child atteine
Be liklihed syn she is nat bareine
There fil as it befallith tymes moo
Whan that this childe had souked but a throwe
This Markas thouȝt in his hert so
To tempte his wif hir sadnesse for to knowe
That he ne miȝt out of his herte throwe
This merueilous desire his wif to assay
Nedeles god wot he thouȝt hir for to affray
He had assaied hir I nouȝ before
And fonde her euer good what neded it
Hir for to tempte and alwey more ⁊ more
Thouȝ som men preise it for a sotil witt
But as for me I sey euel it sit
To assaye a wif whan it is no nede
And putten hir in anguissh ⁊ in drede
For wich this Markas wrouȝt in this manere
He cam alone aniȝt there as she lay
With sterne face and with vgli chere
And seid thus Grisilde that day
That I you took of your pouer array
And put you in estat of high noblesse
Ye haue nat forgeten that as I gesse
I sey Grisilde this present dignite
In wich that I haue put you as I trowe
Maketh you nat foryeteful for to be
That I you took in poore estat ful lowe
For any wele ye mot your self knowe
Take hede of eueri word that I you sey
There nis no wiȝt that hereth but we twey
Ye wot your self wel ben that ye cam hiere
In to this hous it is nat longe agoo
And thouȝ to me ye be lef and dere
Vnto my gentiles ye be no thing so
They sein to hem it is gret shame ⁊ woo
For to ben subiectes and to ben in seruage
To the that born art of a smal village
And nameli sith thi douȝter was ybore
These wordes han they spoken douteles
But I desire as I haue don before
To lede my lif with hem in reste and pees
I may in this caas be reccheles
I mot don with thi douȝter for the beste
Nouȝt as I wolde but as my people lest
And yit god wot this is ful loth to me
But natheles withoute your witing
I wol nat don but this wol I quod he
That ye to me assent in this thing
Shewe now your pacience in your werking
That ye me hight and swore in your village
That day that maked was oure mariage
Whan she had herd al this she nat ameued
Neither in word in chere nor countenaunce
For as it semed she was nat agreued
She said lord al lith in your plesaunce
My childe and I with hertly obeissaunce
Ben youres alle and ye mow saue and spille
Your oughne thing werketh after your oughne wille
Ther may no thing god so my soule saue
Liking to you that may displese me
Ne I desire no thing for to haue
Ne drede for to lese saue onli ye
This wil is myn hert and ay shal be
No lengthe of tyme or deth may this deface
Ne torne my corage to non othir place
Glad was this Markas of hir ansuering
But yet it semed as it were nat so
Al drery was his chere and his loking
Whan that he wolde out of the chambre goo
Sone aftir this afurlong weye or tuo
He priueli hath tolde al his entent
Vn to a man / and to his wif him sent
A maner of Sergeaunt was this priue man
The wich that feithful ofte founden he hadde
In thinges grete and eke such folk wel can
Don execucion of thinges badde
The lord knew wel that he him loued ⁊ drad
And whan this Sergeaunt wist his lordes wil
In to the chambre he stalked him ful stil
Madame he seid ye mot for yeue it me
Thouȝ I do thing to wich I am constreined
Ye ben so wise that ful wel knowe ye
That lordes hestes mow nat ben yfeined
They mow wel be / bewailed ⁊ compleined
But men miȝt nede vnto her lust obeye
And so wol I there is no more to seye
This child I am comaunded for to take
He spak nomore but out the childe he hent
Despitousli and gan a chere make
As thouȝ he wolde haue slain it or he went
Grisilde mut al suffre and al consent
And as a lombe she sitteth meke ⁊ stille
And lete this cruel sergeaunt don his wille
Suspecious was the diffame of this man
Suspect his face suspect his word also
Suspect the tyme in wich he this bigan
Allas hir douȝter that she loued so
She wend he wold ha slain it riȝt tho
But natheles she wepte neuer nor siked
Conforming hir to that the Markas liked
But ate last to speken she began
And mekely she to the Sergeaunt preide
So as he was a worthi gentil man
That she miȝt kisse hir childe or that it deide
And in hir arme this litil childe she leide
With sad face and gan the childe to kisse
And lulled it and aftir gan it blisse
And thus she said in hir benigne vois
Fare wel my childe I shal the neuer se
But sith I haue marked the with the crois
Of that fader blessid mot he be
That for vs deyed vpon a cros of tre
Thi soule litil child I him betake
For this niȝt shalt thou deie for my sake
I trowe that to a Norrice in this caas
It had ben routhe this hardnesse for to se
Wel miȝt a moder thanne haue cried allas
But natheles so sad and stedfast was she
That she endured al aduersite
And to the sergeaunt mekely she saide
Haue hiere agein your litil yong maide
Goth now quod she and do my lordes hest
But oo thing wol I pray you of your grace
That but my lord forbad you ate lest
Burieth this litil body in som place
There bestes ne birdes it to race
But he no word wolde to that purpos sey
But took the childe and went vpon his wey
This Sergeaunt cam to his Lord agein
And of Grisildes wordes and hir chere
He tolde him point for point in short ⁊ plein
And him presenteth with his douȝter dere
Som what this lord hath routhe in his manere
But natheles his purpos helde he stille
As lordes don whan they wil haue her wille
And bad his sergeaunt that he priuely
Shulde this childe softe wynde ⁊ wrappe
With al the circumstaunce tenderly
And carie it in a cofre or in a lappe
But vpon peine his hed of for to swappe
That noman shulde knowe of this entent
Ne whens it cam ne whider that it went
But at Boloigne to his sustir dere
That thilk tyme of Pauik was Countesse
He shulde it take and shewe hir this matere
Beseching hir to don hir besinesse
The childe to fostre in al gentilnesse
And whos childe it was he bad him hide
From eueri wiȝt that ouȝt that may betide
The Sergeaunt goth ⁊ hath fulfilled this thing
But to this Markas now retorne we
For now goth he ful fast ymagining
If be his wifes chere he miȝt se
Or be hir worde parceiue that she
Were chaunged but neuer coude he fynde
But euer in oon ylik sad and kynde
As glad as humble as besi in seruise
And eke in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to him in eueri maner wise
Ne of hir douȝter nouȝt a word spak she
Non accident for non aduersite
Was sene in hir ne neuer hir douȝter name
Ne nempned she in ernest ne in game
IN this estat there passed ben foure yere
Or she with childe was but as god wolde
A knaue childe she bare be this Waltere
Ful gracious and fair to be holde
And whan that folk it to his fader tolde
Nat only he but al his contre merye
Was for this child and god they thanke ⁊ herie
Whan it was tuo yere olde and from the brest
Departed of his Norrice vpon a day
This Markis cauȝt yit another lest
To tempte his wif yit ofter if he may
O nedeles was she tempted in assay
But wedded men knewe no mesure
Whan they finde a pacient creature
Wif quod this Markas ye haue herd this
My people sekirly bereth oure mariage
And namely sith my sone yborn is
Now is it wers than euer in al oure age
The murmour sleth myn herte ⁊ myn corage
For to myn eres comth the vois so smerte
That it wel ny destroied hath myn herte
Now sein they thus whan Walter is agoon
Than shal the blood of Ianicle succede
And ben oure lord for other haue we non
Such wordes sem my people out of drede
Wel ouȝt I of such murmour take hede
For certeinly I drede such sentence
Thouȝ they nouȝt pleine ⁊ speke in myn audience
I wolde lyue in pees if that I miȝt
Therfore I am disposed outterly
As I his suster serued be niȝt
Riȝt so thinke I to serue him priuely
This warne I you that ye nat sodeinly
Out of your self for no woo shuld outrey
Beth pacient and therof I you prey
I haue quod she seid thus and euer shal
I wol no thing ne nil no thing certein
But as you list nouȝt greueth me at al
Thouȝ that my douȝter and my sone be slain
At your comaundement this is to sein
I haue nouȝt nat had no part of children tweine
But first sekenesse and aftir woo and peine
Ye ben oure lord doth with your ougne thing
Right as you list aske no rede at me
For as I left at hom al my clothing
Whan I first cam to you riȝt so quod she
Left I my wil and al my liberte
And toke your clothing wherfor I you prey
Do your plesaunce I wol your lust obey
And certes if I had prescience
Your wil to knowe or ye your lust me tolde
I wold it don withoute necligence
But now I wot your lust and what ye wolde
Al your plesaunce ferme ⁊ stable I holde
For wist I that my deth wold you ease
Riȝt gladli wold I deie you to plese
Deth may nat take no comparison
Vn to your loue / and whan this Markas say
The constaunce of his wif he cast adoun
His yhen tuo and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre al this array
And forth he goth with dreri contenaunce
But to his hert it was ful gret plesaunce
This vgli sergeaunt in the same wise
That hir douȝter cauȝt riȝt so he
Or wers / if men can wers deuise
Hath hent hir sone that ful was of beaute
And euer in oon so pacient was she
That she no chere made of heuinesse
But kist hir sone ⁊ aftirward gan it blesse
Saue this she praid him if that he miȝt
Hir litil sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tender lymes delicat to siȝt
For foules and for bestes it to saue
But she non othir ansuere of him miȝt haue
He went his wey as him no thing rouȝt
But to Boloigne he it tenderli brouȝt
This Markas wondred euer lenger the more
Vpon hir pacience / and if that he
Ne had sothli knowen there before
That parfitly hir children loued she
He wolde haue wende that of som sotilte
And of malice and for cruel corage
That she had suffred this with sad visage
But wel he knew that next him self certein
She loued hir children best in eueri wise
But now of wommen wolde I aske fain
If these assayes miȝt nat suffise
What coude a sturdi husbond more deuise
To preue hir wifehod and hire stedfastnesse
And he continuyng euer in sturdinesse
But there ben folk of such condicion
That whan they haue certain purpos take
They can nat stinte of her entencion
But riȝt as they were bounden vnto a stake
They wol nat of ther first purpos slake
Riȝt so this Markas fulli hath purposed
To tempte his wif as he was first disposed
He waiteth if be worde or contenaunce
That she to him was chaunged of corage
But neuer coude he finde variaunce
She was ay oon in hert and in visage
And ay the forther that she was in age
The more true if it were possible
She was to him in loue ⁊ more penible
For wich it semed thus that of them tuo
Ther nas but oo wil for as Walter lest
The same lust was hir plesaunce also
And god be thonked al fel for the best
She shewid wel for no worldli vnrest
As wif as of hir self no thing ne shulde
Wol in effect but as hir husbond wolde
The slaunder of Walter ofte ⁊ wide sprad
That of a cruel hert so wickedly
For he a poore womman wedded had
Hath mordered bothe his children priuely
Such murmour was among hem comonly
No wonder is for to the peoples ere
Ther cam no word but that they mordred were
For wich ther as his people ther before
Had loued him wel the slaunder of his diffame
Made hem that they him hated therfore
To ben a morderer is an hateful name
But natheles for ernest or for game
He of his cruel purpos nolde stinte
To tempte his wif was set al his entent
Whan that this douȝter .xij. yere was of age
He to the court of Rome in sotill wise
Enformed of his wil sent his message
Comaunding hem such bulles to deuise
As to his cruel purpos may suffise
Hou that the Pope as for his peoples rest
Bad him to wedde anothir if him lest
I sey he bad they shuld conterfete
The Popes bulles making mencioūn
That he hath leue his first wif to lete
As by the popes dispensacion
To stinte rancour and dissencioūn
Betwen him and the people thus said the bulle
The wich they han publisshed ate fulle
The rude people as it no wonder is
Wend ful wel that it had be riȝt so
But whan these tidinges cam to Grisildes
I deme that hir herte was ful woo
But she ilik sad for euermo
Disposid was this humble creature
The aduersite of fortune al to endure
Abiding euer his lust and his plesaunce
To whom that she was youen hert and al
As to hir verri worldli suffisaunce
But shortli I this story tellen shal
This Markas writen hath in special
A letter in wich he shewith his entent
And secretli he it to Boloigne sent
The Erle of Paui wich that had tho
Wedded his suster praid he specially
To bringen hom agein his children tuo
In honourable estat / al openly
But oo thing / he praid him vtterly
That he no wiȝt thouȝ men wold enquere
Shuld nat telle whos children that they were
But sey the maiden shuld wedded be
Vnto the Markas of Saluce anon
And as this Erle was praid so did he
For at the day set he on his weie is gon
And forth he rod ful fast and that anon
Toward Saluce this maide for to guide
Hir yong brothir riding hir beside
Arraied was toward hir mariage
This fressh May ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother wich that vij yeer was of age
Arrayed eke ful fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse ⁊ in glad chere
Toward Saluces shaping her iourney
From day to day they riden in her wey
Among al this after his wicked vsage
This Markas yit his wif to tempte more
To the vtterest pref of hir corage
Fulli to haue experience and lore
If that she was as stedfast as before
He on a day in open audience
Ful boistously hath seid hir this sentence
Certes Grisilde I had I nouȝ plesaunce
To haue you to my wif for your godenesse
As for your trouthe and for your obeissaunce
Nouȝt for your lynage ne for your richesse
But now knowe I in verri sothfastnesse
That in gret lordshipe if I me wel auise
There is gret seruitute in sondri wise
I may nat do as eueri plouȝ man may
My people constreineth me to take
An othir wif and crien day be day
And eke the pope rancour for to slake
Consenteth it that dar I vndertake
And truly thus moch wol I you sey
My newe wif is coming bi the wey
Be strong of herte and voide anon hir place
And that dower that ye brouȝt me
Take it agein I graunte of my grace
Retorneth to youre faders hous quod he
No man may alwey haue prosperite
With euen hert I rede you to endure
The strok of fortune or of auenture
And she agein ansuerde in pacience
My lord quod she I wot and wist alwey
Hou that bitwen your magnificence
And my pouerte no wiȝt ne can nor may
Maken comparison it is no nay
I ne helde me neuer digne in no manere
To be your wif ne yit your chamberer
And in this hous there ye me lady made
The high god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neuer helde me lady ne mastresse
But humble seruaunt to your worthinesse
And euer shal whil that my lif may dure
Aboue eueri worldli creature
That ye so long of youre benignite
Han holde me in honour and nobley
Where as I was nat worthi for to be
That thank I god and you to whom I pray
For yelde it you ther is nomore to sey
Vn to my fader gladli wol I wende
And with him duelle vnto my lyfes ende
There I was fostred a child ful smal
Til I be ded my lif there wol I lede
A widewe clene in body hert and al
For sith I yaf to you my maidenhede
And am your true wif it is no drede
God shelde such a lordes wif to take
Anothir man to husbond or to make
And of your newe wif god of his grace
So graunt you welthe and prosperite
For I wol gladli yelde hir my place
In wich that I blisful was wont to be
For sith it liketh you my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertes rest
That I shal gon I wol gon whan you lest
But there as ye me profre such dowarie
As I first brouȝt it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecchid clothis no thing faire
The wich to me were hard now for to fynde
O gode god hou gentil and hou kynde
Ye semed by youre speche and your visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
But soth is said algate I fynde it true
For in effect it preued is on me
Loue is nat olde as whan that is newe
But certes lord for non aduersite
To dye in this cas it shal nat be
That euer in word or werk I shal repent
That I you yaf myn hert in hool entent
My lord ye wot that in my fadres place
Ye did me stripe out of my poore wede
And richeli me clad of your grace
To you brouȝt I nat elles out of drede
But filthe and nakidnesse of maidenhede
And hiere agein my clothing I restore
And eke my wedding ring for euer more
The remenaunt of youre Iewellis redi be
Within your chambre I dar saueli sein
Naked out of my faders hous quod she
I cam and naked mot I torne agein
Al your plesaunce wold I folwe fein
But yit I hope it be nat your entent
That I smokles out of your paleis went
Ye coude nat do so dishonest a thing
That thilke wombe in wich youre childre lay
Shuld before the people in my walking
Be sein al bare wher fore I you pray
Lat me nat lik a worme go bi the way

O monstre that so sotilli canst peinte
The yiftes vnder hewe of stedfastnesse
That thou deceiuest bothe more and lesse
Whi hast thou Ianuarie thus deceiued
That haddest him for thi ful frend receiued
And now thou hast beraft him bothe his yhen
For sorwe of wich desireth to dyen
Allas this noble Ianuarie the fre
Amid his lust and his prosperite
Is wexen blinde and that al sodeinli
He wepeth he waileth as pitousli
And there with al the fire of ielousy
Lest that his wif shuld falle in som foly
So brent his hert that he wold sein
That som man bothe him and hir had slain
For nouthir after his deth ne in his lif
Ne wolde he that she were no loue ne wif
But euer lyue lik a widewe in clothes blake
Shuld as the turtil hath lost hir make
But at last aftir a month or twey
His sorwe gan to swage soth to sey
For whan he wist it miȝt non othir be
He pacientli took his aduersite
Saue out of doute he may nat for gon
That he nas ielous euer in oon
Wich ielousie it was so outrageous
That neither in halle ne in othir hous
Ne in non othir place neuer the moo
He nolde suffre hir for to ride ne go
But yef that he had hond on hir alwey
For wich ful ofte wepeth fressh May
That loueth Damyan so benigly
That she mot outher dyen sodeinli
Or ellis she must han him as hir list
She waiteth whan hir herte wold brest
Vpon that othir side Damyan
Becom is the sorwefullest man
That euer was that neither niȝt ne day
Ne miȝt he speke a word to fressh May
As to his purpos of no such matere
But if that Ianuarie must it hiere
That had an hond vpon hir euermo
But natheles be writing to and fro
And preue signes wist he what she ment
And she knewe eke the fyne of his entent
O Ianuarie what miȝt it the availe
Thouȝ thou miȝt se as fer as shippes saile
For as good is blinde deceiued be
As ben deceiued whan a man may se
Lo Argus wich that had an C yhen
For al that euer he coude poure or prien
Yit was he blint as god wot so ben moo
That wenen wiseli that it be nat so
Passe ouer is an ese I sey nomore
This fressh May that I spak of before
In warme wex hath prented the cliket
That Ianuarie bar of the smal wiket
Bi wich in to his gardin ofte he went
And Damyan that knew al hir entent
The cliket counterfeted priueli
There is nomore to sey but hastili
Som wonder be this cliket shal betide
Wich ye shul hiere if ye wol abide
O noble Ouide ful soth seist thou god wot
What sleiȝt it is thouȝ it be long and hoot
That loue nil finde it out in som manere
Be Priamus and Tisbe may ye lere
Thouȝ they were kept long and streit ouer al
They ben acorded rouning throuȝ a wal
There no wiȝt coude ha founden such a sleiȝte
But now to purpos or that dayes viij
Were passed or that the month of Iuyl befel
That Ianuarie hath cauȝt so gret a wil
Throuȝ egging of his wif him for to pley
In his gardyn and no wiȝt but they twey
That in a morwe vnto this May seith he
Rise vp my wif my loue my lady fre
The turtles vois is herd my doue so swete
The winter is gon with his reynes wete
Com forth now with thin yhen columbine
Hou moch fairer ben thi brestes than is wyne
The gardyn is enclosed al aboute
Com forth my swete spouse for out of doute
Thou hast me wounded in myn hert o wif
No spot ne knewe I in the al my lif
Com forth and let vs taken oure desport
I chas the for my wif and my comfort
Such olde leude wordes vsed he
On Damyan a signe made she
That he shuld go before with his cliket
This Damyan than hath opened the wiket
And in he sterte and that in such manere
That no wiȝt miȝt him se or hiere
And stille he sat vnder a bussh anon
This Ianuarie as blinde as any ston
With Mayus in his hond ⁊ no wiȝt mo
In to this fressh gardyn is agoo
And clapt to the wiket sodeinli
Now wif quod he hiere nis but ye and I
Thou art the creature that I best loue
For bi that lord that sit in heuen aboue
Leuer I had to dyen on a knif
Than the offende true dere wis
For goddes sake think hou I the ches
Nouȝt for no couetise douteles
But onli for loue I had to the
And thouȝ that I be olde and may nat se
Beth to me true and I wol telle you whi
Thre thinges certes shul ye winne therby
First loue of crist and to your self honour
And al myn heritage both toun and tour
I yeue it you make Chartres as you lest
This shal be don to morwe or the sonne reste
So wisli god my soule bringe to blisse
I pray you in couenaunt first ye me kisse
And thouȝ that I be ielous wite me nouȝt
Ye ben so depe emprented in my thouȝt
That whan I consider your beaute
And there with al the vnlikli age of me
I may nat certes thouȝ I shuld dye
Forbere to ben in your companie
For verri loue this is withouten doute
Now kisse me wif and lete vs rome aboute
This fresshe May whan she this wordes herde
Benigly to Ianuarie she ansuerde
But first and forward she began to wepe
I haue quod she god wot a soule to kepe
As wel as ye and also myn honour
And of my widehod that tender flour
Wich that I haue assured in your hond
Whan that the prest to you my body bond
Wherfor I wol ansuere in this manere
Be the leue of you my lord so dere
I pray to god that neuer dawe the day
That I ne sterue as foule as any womman may
If euer I do vnto my kyn that shame
Or ellis if that I empeire so my name
That I be fals and if I do that lak
Do stripe me and put me in a sak
And in the next ryuer do me drenche
I am a gentil womman ⁊ no wenche
Whi speke ye thus but men ben vntrewe
And wommen han of you repref ay newe
Ye can non othir contenaunce I leue
But speke to vs as vntrust and repreue
And with that word she sauȝ where Damyau
Sate in a bussh and cough she began
And with hir fynger a signe made she
That Damyan shuld clymbe vpon a tre
That charged was with fruit and vp he went
For verrili he knew al hir entent
And eueri signe that she couthe make
Wel better than Ianuarie his ougne make
For in a letter she had told him al
Of this mater hou he werken shal
And thus I lete him sitte vpon this perie
Ianuarie and May roming ful merie
Briȝt was the day and blw the firmament
Phebus hath of gold his stremes doun sent
To gladen eueri flour with his gladnesse
He was that tyme in Gemine as I gesse
But litil from at his declinacion
Of Cancer Iouis exaltacion
And so befel that briȝt morwe tide
That in that gardyn on the forther side
Pluto that is king of fairie
And many a lady in his companie
Folwing his wif the quene Proserpine
Ech aftir othir as riȝt as a syne
Whil that she gadered floures in the mede
In Claudian ye may the stories rede
Hou in his grisli carte he hir set
This king of Fairie doun him set
Vpon a benche of turues faire and grene
And riȝt anon thus seid he to the quene
Now wif quod he there may no wiȝt sey nay
The experience so preueth it eueri day
The treson wich that womman doth to man
XC . Ml wel telle I can
Notable of your vntrouthe ⁊ brotilnesse
O noble Salomon richest of richesse
Fulfilled of sapience and worldli glorie
Ful worthi ben thi wordes to memorie
To eueri wiȝt that wit and reson can
Thus preiseth he yit the bounte of man
Among a thousand men yit fond I oon
But of wommen al fonde I non
Thus seith the king that knoweth your wikkidnesse
And Ihuc filius Sirac as I gesse
Ne speketh of you but selde reuerence
A wilde fire and corrupt pestilence
So falle vpon youre bodyes yit to niȝt
Ne se ye nouȝt this honourable kniȝt
Be cause allas that he is blinde and olde
His ougne man shal make him Cookolde
Lo where he sitteth the lecchour on the tre
Now wol I graunt of my mageste
Vnto this olde blinde worthi kniȝt
That he shal haue agein his yhen siȝt
And whan that his wif wold do him vilany
Than shal he knowe al her harlotrie
Bothe in repref of hir and othir moo
Ye shal quod Proserpine wol ye se
Now be my moders soule sir I you swere
That I shal yeue hir sufficiant ansuere
And al wommen aftir for hir sake
That thouȝ they be in any gilt take
With face bolde they shul hem self excuse
And bere hem doun that wolden hem accuse
For lak of ansuere non of hem shal dyen
Al had a man seen a thing with his yhen
Yit shul we wommen visage it hardely
And wepe and swere and chide sotilly
So that the men shul ben as leude as gees
What rekketh me of your auctoritees
I wot wel that this Iewe this Salomoūn
Fonde of vs wifes fooles many oon
But thouȝ that he fonde no good womman
Yit hath ther founden many an othir man
Wommen ful trewe ful good ⁊ vertuous
Witnesse of hem that duelle in Cristes hous
With martirdom they preued her constaunce
The Romain gestes maketh of hir remembraunce
Of maniy a verri trewue wif also
But sir be nat wroth al be it so
Thouȝ that he seid he fonde no trewe womman
I pray you take the sentence as I telle can
He ment thus that in souerain bounte
Nis non but god neither he ne she
Ey for verri god that nis but oon
What make ye so moch of Salamon
What thouȝ he made a Temple goddes hous
What thouȝ he were riche and glorious
So made he a temple of fals goddes
Who miȝt don a thing that more forboden is
Parde as faire as ye his name plastre
He was a lecchour and an Idolastre
And in his elde he verri god forsook
And if god ne had as seith the book
Spared him for his faders sake he sholde
Haue lost his regne rather than he wolde
I set nouȝt of al the vilanie
That he of wommen wrot a boterflie
I am a womman nedes must I speke
Or ellis swelle til myn herte breke
For sith that ye sey that we be iangles
As euer hool mot I brouke my tresses
I shal nat spare for no curtesie
To speke him harme that wolde vs vilanie
Dame quod this Pluto be no lenger wroth
I yeue it vp but sith I swore myn oth
That I wold graunt him his siȝt ayein
My word shal stonde I warne you certein
I am a king it sit me nat lye
And I quod she a quene of fairie
Hir ansuere shal she haue I vndertake
Lat vs now no wordes herof make
Forsoth I wol no lenger you contrarie
Now lat vs torne ayein to Ianuarie
That in the gardyn with his fressh May
Singeth ful merier than the Popingay
You loue I best and shal and othir non
So long aboute the aleyes is he gon
Til he was come agein to that Pyrie
Where as this damyan sitteth ful merye
And high among the fressh leues grene
This fressh May that is so briȝt and shene
Gan for to sighe and seide allas my side
Now sir quod she for ouȝt that may betide
I must haue of the peres that I se
Or I mot dye so sore longeth me
To ete of the smal peres grene
Helpe for hir loue that is heuene quene
I telle you a womman in my plite
May haue to fruit such an appetit
That she may dyen but she it haue
Allas quod he that I had hiere a knaue
That coude climbe allas allas quod he
For I am blinde ya sir no force quod she
But wolde ye vouche sauf for goddes sake
The Pirie within your armes for to take
For wel I wot that ye mistrusten me
Than I climbe shulde wel I nouȝ quod she
So I my foot may sette vpon your bak
Certes quod he therof shal be no lak
Miȝt I you helpe with myn herte blood
He stouped doun and she on his bak stood
And cauȝt hir be a twist and vp she goth
Ladyes I pray you that ye be nat wroth
I can nat glose I am a rude man
And sodeinli anon this Damyan
Gan pullen vp the smok and in he throng
And whan that Pluto saugh this gret wrong
To Ianuarie anon he yaf his siȝt
That he than riȝt wel se miȝt
And whan that he had cauȝt his siȝt agein
Ne was ther neuer of thing so fein
But on his wif his thouȝt was euermo
Vpon the tre he cast his yhen tuo
And saugh that Damian his wif had dressed
In such maner it may nat ben expressed
But if I shulde speke vncurteisly
And vp he yaf a roring and a cry
O strong Lady . stoore what dost thou
And she ansuerd sir what eileth you
Haue pacience and reson in your mynde
I haue you holpen of bothe your yhen blinde
Vp peril of my soule I shal nat lien
As me was tauȝt to hele with your yhen
Was no thing better for to make you se
Than strugle with a man vpon a tre
God wot I did it with ful good entent
Strugle quod he algate in it went
God gif you bothe on shame deth to dyen
He swiued the I sauȝ it with myn yhen
And elles be I hanged bi the hals
And than is quod she my medicine fals
For certeinli if that ye miȝt se
Ye wold nat sey these wordes vnto me
Ye haue som glymering and no parfit siȝt
I se quod he aswel as euer I miȝt
Thanked be god with bothe myn yhen tuo
And be my trouth me thouȝt he did the so
Ye mase mase gode sir quod he
This thank haue I for I made you se
Allas quod she that euer I was so kinde
Now dame quod he let passe al out of mynde
Com a doun my lief and if I haue missaid
God helpe me so as I am euil apaid
But be my faders soule I went haue seen
Hou that this damyan had bi the lein
And that thi smok had lein on thi brest
Ye sir quod she ye may sey as you lest
But sir a man that waketh out of his slepe
He may nat so sodeinli wel take kepe
Vpon a thing and se it so parfitly
Til that he be a waked verrily
Riȝt so a man that long hath blinde I be
Ne may nat sodeinli so wel se
First whan his siȝt is newe come agein
As he that hath a day or tuo seen
Til that your siȝt be sateled awhile
There may ful many a siȝt you beguile
Be war I pray you for be heuene king
Ful many a man weneth to se a thing
And it is al an othir than it semeth
He that mis conceiueth mys demeth
And with that word she lepe doun from the tre
This Ianuarie who is glad but he
He kisseth hir and clippeth hir ful ofte
And on hir wombe he striketh hir ful softe
And to his paleis hom he hath hir lad
Now gode men I pray you al be glad
Thus endeth hiere my tale of Ianuarie
God blisse vs alle and oure lady Seint Marie .
Hic definit fabula Mercatoris
Et Incipit Prologus Armigeri

Ey good oure oost euen
said he tho .
Now such a wif I pray god kepe me fro
Lo such sleiȝtes and subtilitees
In wommen ben for ay as besi as bees
Ben they vs seli men for to deceiue
And from the soth euermore wol they weiue
Be this Marchauntes tale it preueth wel
But douteles as true as any stele
I haue a wif thouȝ that she poore be
But of hir tunge a labbing shrewe is she
And yit she hath an hepe of vices moo
Therof no force lat such thinges go
But wot ye what in counceil be it said
Me rueth sore I am vnto hir teid
For and I shuld reken eueri vice
Wich that she hath I wis I were to nice
And cause whi it shulde reported be
And told to hir of som of this meyne
Of whom it nedeth nat to declare
Syn wommen can vttre such chaffare
And eke my wit suffiseth nat therto
To tellen all wherfor my tale is do
Squier com ner if it your wil be
And sey somwhat of loue for certes ye
Conne theron as moch as any man
Nay sir quod he but such thing as I can
With hertli will for I wil nat rebelle
Agein your lust a tale I wol you telle
Haue me excused if I speke amis
My will is good and lo my tale is this
Hic desinit Prologus Armigeri

div.l: (base) This noble kyng was clepid Kambyuskan
(base) Which in his tyme was of so greet renoun
(base) That ther nas nowher in no Regioun
(base) So excellent a lord in alle thyng
(base) Hym lakked noght that longed to a kyng
(base) As of the secte of which that he was born
(base) He kepte his lay to which that he was sworn
(base) And ther to he was hardy wys and riche
(base) Pietous and Iust and eueremoore yliche
(base) Sooth of his word benigne and honurable
(base) Of his corage as any Centre stable
(base) Yong fressh and strong in armes desirous
(base) As any Bachiler of al his hous
(base) A fair persone he was and fortunat
(base) And kepte alwey so wel Roial estat
(base) That ther nas no wher swich another man
(base) This noble kyng this Tartre Cambyuskan
(base) Hadde two sones on Elfeta his wyf
(base) Of whiche the eldeste highte Algarsyf
(base) That oother sone was clepid Cambalo
(base) A doghter hadde this worthy kyng also
(base) That yongest was and highte Canacee
(base) But for to telle yow al hir beautee
(base) It lyth nat in my tonge nyn my konnyng
(base) I dar nat vndertake so heigh a thyng
(base) Myn englyssh eek is insufficient
(base) It moste been a Rethor excellent
(base) That koude his colours longyng for that Art
(base) If he sholde hire discryuen euery part
(base) I am noon swich I moot speke as I kan
(base) And so bifel that whan this Kambyuskan
(base) Hath twenty wynter born his dyademe
(base) As he was wont fro yeer to yeer I deme

(base) Don crien thurgh out Sarray his Citee
(base) The laste Idus of March after the yeer

div.l: (base) For which the foweles agayn the sonne shene

(base) Agayn the swerd of wynter kene and cold

div.l: (base) He with a manly voys seyde his message
(base) After the forme vsed in his langage
(base) Withouten vice of silable or of lettre
(base) And for his tale sholde seme the bettre

(base) Al be that I kan nat sowne his style

(base) Yet seye I this that as to commune entente

(base) My lige lord on this solempne day

div.l: (base) His newe loue and al his subtiltee
(base) So openly that ther shal no thyng hyde
(base) Wher fore agayn this lusty someres tyde
(base) This Mirour and this ryng that ye may see

(base) Youre excellente doghter that is heere
(base) The vertu of the ryng if ye wol heere
(base) Is this that if hir list it for to were

wel yquit .
And gentilli I preise wel thi witt
Quod the Frankelyn considering thi youthe
So felingli thou spekest . sir I allowe the
As to my dome ther is non that is hiere
Of eloquence that shal be thi pere
If that thou lyue god gif the gode chaunce

For of thi speche I haue gret deinte
I haue a sone and bi the Trinite

He were a man of such discrecion

Straw for your gentilnesse quod oure oost
What Frankelyn parde sir wel thou wost
That ech of you mot tellen ate leste
A tale or tuo or breke his heste
That knowe I wel sir quod the Frankelein
I pray you haueth me nat in disdein
Thouȝ to this man I speke a word or tuo

I wol you nat contrarie in no wise
As fer that al my wittes woll suffise

div.l:
Lordinges quod he in
Chirche whan I preche
I peine me to haue an hautein speche
And ring out as loude as doth a belle
For I can all by roote that I telle
First I pronounce fro whens that I com
And than my bulles shewe I all ⁊ som
Oure liege lordes seall on my patent
I shewe first my body to warent
That noman be so bold prest nor clerk
Me to distourbe of cristes holi werk
And after that than telle I forth my tales
Bulles of Popes and of Cardinales
Of Patriarkes and of busshopis I shewe
And in latyn speke I wordes fewe
To saffron with my predicacion
In eueri village and in eueri toun
This is my teme and shal and euer was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Than shewe I forth my long cristal stones
Ycrammed ful of cloutes and of bones
Relikes ben they as wene they echon
Than haue I of laton a shulder boon
Wich that was of an holi Iewes shepe
Gode men I sey take of my wordes kepe
If that this boon be wasshe in any welle
If cow or calf oxe or shepe swelle
That any worme hath ete or worme ystonge
Take water of that welle and wasshe his tonge
And it is hool anon and yit ferthermore
Of pokkes of scabbes and of eueri sore
Shal eueri shepe be hooll that of this welle
Drinketh a drauȝt take hede eke what I telle
If that the gode man that the bestes oweth
Wool eueri weke or that the cok him croweth
Fasting drinken of that welle a drauȝt
As thilk holi Iewes oure elders tauȝt
His bestes and his store shal multeplie
And sir also it heleth Ielousie
For thouȝ a man befalle in ielous rage
Lat make with this water his potage
And neuer shal he more his wif mistrust
Thouȝ he the soth of hir defaulte wost
Al had she take prestes tuo or thre
Hiere is a metain eke that ye may se
He that his hond wil put in this metayn
He shal haue multeplieng of his grain
Whan he hath sowe be it whete or otes
So that he offre pens orellis grotes
Gode wommen o thing warne I you
If any wiȝt be in this chirche now
That hath do sinne so horrible that he
Dare not for shame of it schriuen be
Or any womman be she yong or olde
That hath made hir husbond Cookholde
Such folk shal haue no power ne no grace
To offre to my relikes in this place
And who so finde him out of such a blame
They wol com vp and offre a goddes name
And I assoile him bi the Auctorite
Wich that by bulle I graunted was to me
Bi this gaude haue I wonne by yere
An hundred mark syn I was Pardoner
I stood lik a Clerk in my pulpit
And whan that leude people is doun set
I preche so as ye han herd before
And telle an hundred fals iapes more
Than peine I to strecche forth my necke
And est and west on the people I becke
As doth a dove sitting on a berne
Myn handes and my tonge gon so yerne
That it is ioye to se my besinesse
Of Auarice and of such cursidnesse
Is al my preching for to make hem fre
To yeue her pens / and namely vnto me

Aqueinted was so with the gode man
Sith that her first knoulage began
That in his hous as famulier was he
As it is possible any frende to be
And forasmuch as this gode man
And eke this monk of wich that I began
Were bothe tuo yborn in oo village
The monk him claimeth as for cosinage
And he ayein he seith nat ones nay
But was as glad therof as foule of day
For to his herte it was a gret plesaunce
Thus ben they knitte with eterne alliaunce
And ech of hem gan othir forto assure
Of bretherhod whil that her lif may dure
Fre was Dan Iohn and nameli of dispence
As in that hous and full of diligence
To don plesaunce and also gret costage
He nouȝt forgat to yeue the lest page
In al that hous but after her degre
He yaf the lord and sith all his meyne
Whan that he cam som man
For wich they were as glad of his
As foule is fain when the sonne vpr
Nomore of this as now for it suffiseth
But so befell this Marchaunt vpon a day
Shope him redi to make his array
Toward the toun of Brugges forto fare
To bye there a porcion of ware
For wich he hath to Parys sent anon
A messanger and praid hath daun Iohn
That he shuld come to seint denys and pley
With him and with his wif a day or twey
Or he to Brugges went in all wise
This / noble Monke of wich I you deuise
Hath of his abbot as him list licence
Be cause he was aman of high prudence
And eke an officer out for to ride
To se her graunges and her bernes wide
And vnto Seint Denys he cometh anon
Who was so welcome as my lord dain Iohn
Oure dere Cosin ful of curtesie
With him brouȝt he a Iubbe of Maluiesie
And eke an othir full of fyne vernage
And volatile / as ay was his vsage
And thus I lete hem ete and drink and pley
This Marchaunt and this monk a day or twey
The thrid day this Marchaunt vp ariseth
And on his nedes sadli him aviseth
And vp in to his Counterhous geth he
To reken with himself wel may be
Of thilk yere hou that it with him stood
And hou that he dispended had his good
And if that he encresed were or non
His bokes and his bagges many oon
He leith before him on his counting boorde
Ful riche was his tresoure and his hoorde
For wich ful faste his countorur dore he shette
And eke he nolde that noman shuld him lette
Of his accountes for the mene tyme
And thus he sat til it was passid prime
Dan Iohn was risen in the morwe also
And in the gardyn walketh to and fro
And hath his thinges said ful curteisly
This gode wif cam walking priuely
In to the gardin there he walketh softe
And him salueth as she hath don ofte
A maide childe cam in her companie
Wich as hir lust she may gouerne ⁊ guie
For yit vnder the yarde was the maide
O dere cosin myn dan Iohn she saide
What eileth you so rathe forto rise
Nece quod he it ouȝt Inow suffise
V. houres forto slepe vpon a niȝt
But if it were for an olde appalled wiȝt
As ben these wedded men that lyen ⁊ dare
As in a forrow sitteth a weri hare
Were all forstrauȝt with houndes gret and smale
But dere Nece whi be ye so pale
I trowe certes that oure gode man
Hath you labored sith the niȝt began
That you were nede to resten hastily
And with that word he lough ful merily
And of his ougne thouȝt he wex al red
This faire wif gan to shake her hed
And seid thus . ye god wot all quod she
Nay cosin myn it stant nat so with me
For be that god that yaf me soule ⁊ lif
In al the reialme of Fraunce is there no wif
That lesse lust hath to that sori pley
For I may singe allas and welaway
That I was born . but to no wiȝt quod she
Dare I nat telle hou that it stant with me
Wherfor I think out of this lond to wende
Orellis of my self to make an ende
So full am I of drede and eke of care
This monke began vpon this wif to stare
And seide allas my Nece god forbede
That ye for any sorwe or any drede
Fordo your self but telle me your gref
Parauenture I may in your mischef
Counseile or helpe and therfor telle me
Al your annoye for it shal be secre
For on my portos I make an oth
That neuer in my lif for lef or loth
Ne shal I of no counseill you bewrey
The same agein quod she to you I seye
Be god and be this portos I swere
Thouȝ men me wolde al in peces tere
Ne shal I neuer for to go to helle
Bewreie a word of thing that ye me telle
Nouȝt for no cosinage ne alliaunce
But verrili for loue and affiaunce
Thus ben they sworn and hereupon they kist
And ech of hem tolde othir what hem list
Cosin quod she if that I had aspace
As I haue non and nameli in this place
Than wold I telle a legende of my lif
That I haue suffred syn that I was a wif
With myn husbond al be he be your cosin
Nay be god quod this monk ⁊ be seint Martyn
He is nomore Cosin vnto me
Than is the lef that hangeth on the tre
I clepe him so be seint Denys of Fraunce
To han the more cause of aqueintaunce
Of you / wich I haue loued specialli
Abouen all wommen sikerly
This swere I you on my profession
Tellith your gref lesse he com doun
And hasteth you and goth awey anon
Myn dere loue myn quod she O daun Iohn
Ful leue were me this counseill for to hide
But out it mot it may no lenger abide
Myn husbond is to me the werst man
That euer was sith that the world began
But sith I am his wif it sitteth nat me
To telle no wiȝt of oure priuete
Nouther a bedde ne in non othir place
God shelde I shulde it telle for his grace
A wif ne shal nat sein of hir husbonde
But al honour but as I can vnderstonde
Saue vnto you thus moch I tellen shall
As helpe me god he is nat worth at all
In no degre the value of a flie
But yit me greueth most his nigardie
And wel ye wot that wommen naturally
Desiren thinges vj. as wel as I
They wolden that her husbondes shulde be
Hardi and wise and riche and therto fre
And buxom to his wif and fressh abedde
But bi that ilke lord that for vs bledde
For his honour myself for to array
Asonday next I must nedes pay
An hundred Frankes or ellis I am lorn
Yit were me leuer that I were vnborn
Than me were don slaunder or vilanie
And if myn husbond miȝt eke espie
I nere but lost and therfor I you pray
Lene me this somme or ellis / mot I deye
Dan Iohn I sey lene me these hundred Frankes
Parde I wol nat faile you my thankes
If that you list to don that I you sey
For a certain day I wol you pay
And to do you what plesaunce ⁊ seruice
That I may don riȝt as you list deuise
And but I do god tak on me vengeaunce
As foule as euer had Genelon of Fraunce
This gentil monk ansuerd in this manere
Now truli myn ougne lady dere
I haue quod he on you so gret routhe
That I you swere and pliȝt you my trouthe
That whan your husbond is to Flaunders fare
I wol deliuer you out if this care
For I wol bringe you an hundred Franks
And with that word he cauȝt hir bi the flanks
And hir embraceth hard and kisseth hir ofte
Goth now your wey quod he al stille ⁊ softe
And let vs dyne as sone as that ye may
For be my chilindre it is prime of the day
Goth now and beth as trewe as I shal be
Now ellis god forbede sir quod she
And forth she goth as ioly as a pye
And bad the cokes that they shuld hem hye
So that men miȝt dyne and that anon
Vp to hir husbond is this wif gon
And knokketh at his Countyre dore boldeli
Who is there quod he Petir it am I
Quod she / what sir / hou long wil ye faste
Hou longe wol ye hiere rekne and cast
Your sommes and your bokes and your thinges
The deuel haue part of all such rekeninges
Ye han ynouȝ parde of goddes sonde
Com doun to day and let your bagges stonde
Ne be ye nat ashamed that dain Iohn
Shal fasting al this day elenge gon
What let vs hiere a messe and go we dyne
Wif quod this man litill canst thou deuine
The curious besinesse that we haue
For of vs chapmen so god me saue
And be that lord that cleped is Seint Ive
Scarsli amonges xij . x shal thriue
Continualli lasting vnto oure age
We mow wel make chere and a good visage
And driue forth the world as it may be
And kepe oure estat in priuete
Til we be ded or ellis that we pley
A pilgrimage / or gon out of the wey
And therfor haue I gret necessite
Vpon this queint world to auise me
For euer mot we stonde in drede
Of hap ⁊ fortune in oure chapmanhede
To morwe wol I go to morwe at day
And come agein as sone as euer I may
For wich my dere wif I the beseke
As be to eueri wiȝt buxom and meke
And for to kepe oure good be curious
And honestli gouerne wel oure hous
Thou hast ynouȝ in eueri maner wise
That to a thrifti houshold may suffise
The lakketh non array ne non vitaill
Of siluer in thi purs shalt thou nat faill
And with that word his Countor dore he shette
And doun he goth no lenger wolde he lette
But hasteli a masse was there saide
And spedeli the tables were yleide
And to the dyner fast they hem spedde
And richeli this monk the chapman fedde
And aftir dyner Dan Iohn soberly
This chapman toke aside and priueli
He seid him thus Cosin it stondeth so
That wel I se to Brugges wol ye goo
God and seint Austyn kepe you and guide
I pray you Cosin wiseli that ye ride
Gouerneth you also of your diet
Attempreli and nameli in this hete
Betwen vs tuo nedeth no straunge fare
Fare wel cosin god shielde you from care
And if any thing be day or be niȝt
If it ly in my power ⁊ in my miȝt
That ye wol comaunde in any wise
It shal be don riȝt as ye wol deuise
But o thing or ye gon if it may be
I wolde pray you to lene me
An C frankes for a weke or tweye
For certein bestes that I mot beye
To store with a place that is oures
God helpe me so I wolde it were yours
I shal nat faill sureli at my day
Nat for a thousand frankes a myle way
But lat this thing be secre I you prey
For yit to niȝt these bestes mot I bey
And fare now wel myn ougne cosin dere
Graunt mercy of your cost and of your chere
This noble Marchant gentilli anon
Ansuerd and seid O cosin myn daun Iohn
Now sikerli this is a smal request
My gold is yours whan that it you lest
And nat onli my gold but my chaffare
Take what ye list god shelde that ye spare
But o thing is this ye knowe it wel ynouȝ
Of chapmen / that her mony is her plouȝ
We mow creance whil we han a name
But goldeles for to ben it is no game
Paieth it ayein whan it lieth in your ese
After my miȝt ful fain wol I you please
These hundred frankes he fet forth anon
And priueli he took hem to dain Iohn
No wiȝt in al this world wist of this lone
Sauing this Marchaunt ⁊ dan Iohn alone
They drinke and speke rome awhile ⁊ pleye
Til that dan Iohn rideth to his abbeye
The morne cam and forth this Marchant rideth
To Flaunders ward his prentice wel him guideth
Til he cam in to Brugges merily
Now goth this Marchaunt fast and besily
Aboute his nedes and bieth and creaunceth
He nouther pleieth at the dys ne daunceth
But as a Marchant shortli for to telle
He ledeth his lif and there I lete him duelle
The Sonday next the Marchant was a gon
To seint Denys ycom is Dain Iohn
With croune and berd all fressh and newe I shaue
In al the hous there nas so litill a knaue
Ne no wiȝt elles that he ne was ful fain
That my lord dain Iohn was come agein
And shortli to the point riȝt for to gon
This faire wif accorded with dain Iohn
That for these C Franks he shuld all niȝt
Haue hir in his armes bolt vpriȝt
And this accorde parformed was in dede
In merthe al niȝt a besi lif they lede
Til it was day that dain Iohn went his way
And bad the meyne farewell and haue good day
For non of them ne no wiȝt in the toun
Hath of dain Iohn riȝt non suspecciou
And forth he rideth hom to his abbey
Or where him list nomore of him I sey
This Marchaunt when ended was the faire
To Seint Denys he gan for to repaire
And with his wif makith feste and chere
And tellith hir that chaffare is so dere
That nedes mot he make a cheuisshaunce
For he was bounde in a reconisaunce
To paie xx thousand sheldes anon
For wich this Marchaunt is to Parys gon
To borwe of certain frendes that he hadde
A certain of frankes and som with him he ladde
And whan that he was com in to the toun
For gret chierte and gret affeccioūn
Vnto dain Iohn he first goth him to pley
Nat for to axe or borwe of him money
But for to wete and se of his welfare
And for to tellen him of his chaffare
As frendes som whan they be met I fere
Dain Iohn him maketh feste ⁊ meri chere
And he him tolde ayein ful specially
Hou he had wel ybouȝt and graciousli
Thanked be god al hooll his marchandise
Saue that he maist in al maner wise
Make a cheuesshaunce as for his best
And than he shuld be in ioye and in rest
Dain Iohn ansuerd certes I am fain
That ye in hele ar com hom agein
And if that I were riche so haue I blisse
Of twenti thousand sheldes shulde ye nat mysse
For ye so kindeli this othir day
Lent me gold and as I can ⁊ may
I thank you be god and be seint Iame
But natheles I took it vnto oure dame
Your wif at hom the same gold agein
Vpon your benche she wot it wel certein
Be certein toknes that I can you telle
Now be your leue I may no lenger duelle
Oure Abbot wol out of this toun anon
And in his companie nedes mut I gon
Grete wel oure dame myn ougne Nece swete
And fare wel dere cosin til we efte mete
This Marchaunt wich that was ful war ⁊ wise
Creaunced hath and paid eke at Parys
To certain Lumbardes redi in her hond
The somme of golde and gat of hem his bond
And hom he goth mery as a Popingay
For wel he knew he stood in such array
That nedes mut he winne in that viage
A thousand frankes aboue all his costage
His wif ful redi met him at the gate
As she was wont of olde vsage algate
And al that niȝt in merthe they ben set
For he was riche and clerli out of dette
Whan it was day this Marchaunt gan embrace
His wif al newe and kist hir on hir face
And vp he goth and makith it ful touȝ
Nomore quod she be god ye haue ynouȝ
And wantounli agein with him she pleide
Til ate last this Marchaunt seide
Be god quod he I am a litill wroth
With you my wif al thouȝ it be me loth
And wot ye whi be god as that I gesse
That ye han made a maner straungenesse
Betwen me and my cosin Dan Iohn
Ye shuld haue warned me or I had gon
That he you had an hundred Frankes paid
Be redi tokne he helde him euill apaid
For that I to him spak of cheuesshaunce
Me semed so as be his contenaunce
But natheles be god oure heuene king
I thouȝt to aske of him no thing
I pray the wif ne do nomore so
Telle me alwey or I from the goo
If any dettour hath in myn absence
Ypaid the lest throuȝ thi necligence
I miȝt him axe a thing that he hath paid
This wif nat was aferd ne affraid
But boldeli she said ⁊ that anon
Marie I defie the fals Monk dan Iohn
I kepe nat of his toknes neuer a dell
He took me certein gold this wot I well
What euil thedom com in his monkes snoute
For god it wot I wende withoute doute
That he had yeue it me because of you
To don ther with myn honour ⁊ my prow
For cosinage and eke for bele chere
That he hath had ful ofte tymes here
But sith I se I stonde in this disioynt
I wol you ansuere shortli to the point
Ye han mo slak dettours than am I
For I wol paie you wel and redily
From day to day and if so be I faile
I am your wif score it vpon my taill
And I shal paie as sone as euer I may
For be myn trouthe I haue on myn array
And nat on wast bestowed it eueri dell
And for I haue bestowed it so well
For your honoure for goddes sake I sey
As beth nat wroth but let vs laugh and pley
Ye shul my Ioli body han to wedde
Be god I wol not pay you but abedde
Foryeue it me myn ougne spouse dere
Turne hiderward and makith better chere
This Marchaunt saw ther was no remedie
And for to chide it were but sely
Sith that the thing may nat amended be
Now wif he seid and I foryeue it the
But bi thi lif ne be nomore so large
Kepe bet thi good this yeue I the in charge
Thus endeth my tale and god vs sende
Tailling Inouȝ vnto oure lyues ende
Hiere endeth the Shipmannes tale
And the hoost beginneth to speke
Wel caid bi corpus dominus quod oure oost
Now long mot thou saile be the cost
Sir gentil mastir gentill Maryner
God yeue the monk a thousand last quadyere
A ha felawes beth war of such a iape
The monk put in the mannes hood an Ape
And in his wifes eke be Seint Austyn
Draweth monkes nomore vnto youre yn
But now passe ouer and lat vs seke aboute
Who shal now telle first of al this route
An othir tale / and with that word he seide
As curteisli as it had ben a maide
My lady Prioresse be your leue
So that I wist
I wold demen that
A tale next if so were
Now wol ye vouch saf
Gladli quod she and seid as here
Hiere beginneth the P dūns noster
O lord oure lord thi name hou merueilous .
Is in this large world ysprad quod she .
For nat onli thi laude precious
Parformed is be men of dignite
But bi the mouth of childern thi bounte
Parformed is / for on the brest souking
Somtime shewen they thin herying
Wherfor in laude as I best can or may
Of the / and of the white lely flour
Wich that the bar and is a maiden alway
To telle a story I wol do my labour
Nouȝt that I may encrece hir honour
For she hir self is honour and the roote
Of bounte next hir sone and soules bote
O moder maide . O maide moder fre .
O bussh vnbrent brenning in Moises siȝt
That rauesshedest doun from the deite
Throuȝ thin humblesse / the gost that in the liȝt
Of whoz vertu whan he thi gost liȝt
Counceiued was the faders sapience
Helpe me to telle it in thi reuerence
Lady thi bounte and thi magnificence
Thi vertu and thi gret humilite
There may no tunge expresse in no science
For sometime lady or men praien to the
Thou gost before of thi bengnite
And getest vs the liȝt of thi praiere
To guiden vs vnto thi sone so dere
My conning is so weike O blissfull quene
For to declare thi gret worthinesse
That I ne may nat the weiȝte sustene
But as a childe of twelue olde or lesse
That can vnnethe any word expresse
Riȝt so fare I and therfor I you pray
Guideth my song that I shal of you sey
Hiere beginneth the prioresses tale
de Alma redemptoris mater

l.hi: Was in Acie in a gret cite

div.l: Amonges cristen folk a Iewry
Susteined be a lord of that contre
For foule vsure and lucre of vilanie
Hatefull to crist and his companie
And throuȝ this strete men miȝt ride or wende
For it was fre / and open at either ende /
A litill scole of cristen folk there stood
Doun at the ferther ende in wich ther were
Childern an hepe ycomen of cristen blood
That lerned in that scole there by yere
Such maner doctrine as men vsed there
This is to sey to singe ⁊ to rede
As smale childern don in her childhede
Amonges these childern was a widewes sone
A litil clergeon that vij yere was of age
That day be day to scole was his wone
And eke also where he saw the ymage
O cristes moder had he in vsage
As him was tauȝt to knele adoun ⁊ sey
His Aue maria as he went bi the wey
Thus hath this widewe hir litill sone I tauȝt
Oure blissed lady cristes moder dere
To worship and to forgete it nouȝt
For seli child wil alwey sone lere
But ay whan I remembre on this matere
Seint Nicholas stant euer in my presence
For he so yong to crist did reuerence
This litil childe his litill book lerning
As he sat in the scole at his primer
Alma redemptoris herd he sing
As childern lerned her Antiphoner
And as he durst he drowe him nere ⁊ nere
And herkened ay the wordes ⁊ the note
Til he the first coude al be rote .
Nat wist he what this Latin was for to say
For he so yong / and tender was of age
But on a day his felawe gan he prey
To expoune him this song in his language
Or telle him whi this song was in vsage
This praid he him to construe and declare
Ful ofte tyme vpon his knees bare
His felawe wich elder was than he
Ansuerd him thus / this song I haue herd sey
Was maked of oure blisfull lady fre
Hir to salue and eke hir forto prey
To ben oure helpe and socour whan we dey
I can nomore expoune in this matere
I lerne song I can but smal gramere
And is this song maked in reuerence
Of cristes moder said this innocent
Now certes I wol do my diligence
To conne it all or Cristemasse be went
Thouȝ that I for my primer shal be shent
And shal be beten thries in an houre
I wol it conne oure lady for to honoure
His felawe tauȝt him homward priuely
From day to day til he coude it be rote
And than he sang it wel and boldely
Thwies a day it passid throuȝ his throte
From word to word according with the note
To scoleward and homward whan he went
Of cristes moder set was his entent
As I haue seid throuȝ out the Iewrie
This litil child as he cam to and fro
Ful merily wolde he singe and crie
O Alma Redemptoris for euermo
The swetnesse his herte perced so
Of cristes moder that to hir to prey
He can nat stinte of singing bi the wey
Oure first foo the serpent Sathanas
That hath in Iewes hertes his waspes nest
Vp swall and said O Hebraik people allas
Is this to you a thing that is honest
That such a boy shal walken as him lest
In your despite and singe of such sentence
Wich is ayenst oure lawes reuerence
From thens forth the Iewes han conspired
This innocent out of this worlde to chace
An homicide therto han they hired
That in an aley had a priue place
And as the childe gan forby for to pace
This cursed Iewe him hent and helde him fast
And kitt his throte and in a pitte him cast
I sey that in a warderobe they him threwe
Where as these Iewes purgen her entraill
O cursed folk of Herodes al newe
What may your euil entent you availl
Morder wil out certain it wol nat faill
And nameli there as the honour of god shal sprede
The blood out crieth on your cursed dede
O martir souded to virginite
Now maist thou sing and folwe euer in oon
The white lambe celestiall quod she
Of wich the grete Euangelist Seint Iohn
In Pathmos wrot . wich seith that they that gon
Beforn this lambe and sing asong al newe
That they neuer flesshly wommen knewe
This pouer widewe awaiteth al that niȝt
Aftir hir litil child but he cam nouȝt
For wich as sone as it was dayes liȝt
With face pale of dreed and besi thouȝt
She hath at the scole and ellis where him souȝt
Til finalli she gan so fer aspie
That he last sene was in the Iewrie
With moders pite within hir brest enclosed
She goth as she were half out of hir mynde
To eueri place where she hath supposed
Be liklihed her litill childe to fynde
And euer on cristes moder meke and kinde
She cried and ate last she wrouȝt
Amonges the cursed Iewes she him souȝt
She freineth and she praieth pitously
To eueri Iewe that duellid in thilk place
To telle hir if hir childe went ouȝt forby
They seiden nay but Ihu of his grace
Yaue in hir thouȝt within alitill space
That in that place aftir hir sone she cried
Where as he was cast in a pitte beside
O gret god that parformest thi laude
Be mouth of Innocentes lo here thi miȝt
This gemme of chastite this Emeraude
And eke of Martirdom the Ruby briȝt
There he with throte ycorue lay vpriȝt
He Alma redemptoris gan to singe
So loude that al the place gan to ringe
The cristen folk that throuȝ the cite went
It cam forto wonder vpon this thing
And hasteli they for the prouost sent
He cam anon withoute tarieing
And herieth crist that is of heuene king
And eke his moder honour of mankinde
