div.l: Et hic incipit Prologus Monachi .
Whan ended was the tale of Melibe
And of Prudence ⁊ hir benignite
Oure oost said as I am a feithfull man
And bi the precious corpus Madrian
I had leuer than a barell Ale
That good leef my wif had herd this tale
She nis no thing of such pacience
As was this Melibeus wif Prudence
Be goddes bones whan I bet my knaues
She bringeth me the gret clubed staues
And crieth sle the dogges euerichon
And breke hem bothe bak and eueri bon
And if any neiȝbor of myn
Wol nat in chirche vnto my wif encline
Or be so hardi to hir to trespace
Whan she comth hom she rampeth in my face
And crieth fals coward wreke thi wif
Be corpus bones I wol haue thi knif
And thou shalt haue my distaf and go spinne
From day to niȝt riȝt thus woll she beginne
Allas she seith that euer I was shape
To wedde a milk soppe or a coward Ape
That wol be ouerlad with eueri wiȝt
Thou darst nat stonde be thi wifes riȝt
This is my lif but that I wol fiȝte
And out at the dore anon I mot me diȝte
Or ellis I am but lost but if that I
Be lik a wood lyon fooll hardy
I wot wel she wol do me sle som day
Som neiȝbour / and than go my way
For I am perlous with knif in honde
Al be it that I dar nat hir withstonde
For she is but in armes be my feith
That shal he finde that hir misdoth or seith
But let vs passe awey from this mater
My lord the monk quod he be meri of chere
For ye shul telle a tale truly
Lo Rouchester stant hiere fast by
Ride forth myn ougne lord breke nat oure game
But be my trouthe I knowe nat youre name
Whethir shal I calle you my lord Dain Iohn
Or dain Thomas or Dain Albon
Of what hous be ye . be your fader kyn
I vowe to god thou hast a full faire skyn
It is a gentil pasture there thou gost
Thou art nat lik a penaunt or a goost
Vpon my feith thou art som officer
Som worthi Sextein or som Selerer
For be my faders soule as to my doom
Thou art a master whan thou art at hom
No poore Cloisterer ne non Novis
But a gouernour wily and wise
And ther with all of brounesse ⁊ of bones
A wel faring persone for the nones
I pray to god yeue him confusion .
That first the brouȝt vnto religion
Thou woldest ha ben a trede foull ariȝt
Haddest thou as gret leue as thou hast miȝt
To parforme thi lust in engendrure
Thou haddest begoten ful many a creature
Allas whi werest thou so wide a cope
God yef me sorwe but and I were pope
Nat onli thou but eueri miȝti man
Thouȝ he were shore ful high vpon his pan
Shuld haue a wif for al this world is lorn
Religion hath take vp al the corn
Of treding . and we borell men ben shrimpes
Of feble trees ther com wrecchid ympes
This makith that oure heires ben so slender
And feble . that they mow nat wel engender
This maketh that oure wifes wol assay
Religious folk for they mow better pay
Of Venus paymentes than mow we
God wot no lusshebornes payen ye
But be nat wroth my lord thouȝ I pley
Ful ofte in game a soth I haue herd seye
This worthi monk took al in pacience
And seid I wol do al my diligence
As fer as souneth in to honeste
To telle you a tale or ellis ij or iij
And if you list to herken hiderward
I wol you sey the lif of Seint Edward
Or ellis Tragedies wol I telle
Of wich I haue an hundred in my selle
Tragedie is to sey a certein story
As olde bokes maken memory
Of him that stood in gret prosperite
And is falle out of high degre
In to miserie and endeth wrecchidly
And they ben versified comonli
Of vj feet wich men clepen exametron
In prose eke ben endited many oon
And eke in metre in many a sondri wise
Lo this declaring ouȝt I now suffise
Now herkeneth if ye like for to hiere
But first I you beseche in this matere
Thouȝ I be ordre telle nat these thinges
Be it of Popes Emperours or Kinges
After her ages as men writen finde
But telle hem som before and som behinde
As it now comth to my remembraunce
Haue me excused of my gouernaunce
Hic definit Prologus Monachi

Et incipit fabula sua de casibus
virorium illustrium .
I wol be waile in maner of Tragedie .
The harme of hem that stonden in high degre .
And fellen so that ther was no remedie .
To bringe hem out of her aduersite .
For certein whan that fortune list to fle .
There may no man the cours of hir witholde
Lat noman trust on blinde prosperite
Be ware of these ensamples true and olde
At Lucifer thouȝ that he an aungel were
And nat a man / at him wol I beginne
For thouȝ fortune may non aungell dere
From hiȝ degre yit fell he for his sinne
Doun in to helle where as he yit is inne
O Lucifer briȝtest of Aungels alle
Now art thou Sathanas thou maist nat twinne
Out of miserie in wich that thou art falle
Loo Adam in the felde of Damassene
With goddes ougne finger wrouȝt was he
And nat begoten of mannes sperme vnclene
And welt all Paradys sauing of oo tre
Had neuer wordli man so high degre
As Adam all he for misgouernaunce
Was driuen out of his high prosperite
To labour and to helle and to mischaunce
Lo Sampson wich that was annunciat
By the aungel long or his natiuite
And was to god almiȝti consecrat
And stood in noblesse whil he miȝt se
Was neuer such an othir as was he
To speke of strengthe and there with hardinesse
But to his wifes tolde he his secre
Throuȝ wich he slew him self for wrecchidnesse
Sampson this noble and miȝti Champioūn
Withouten wepen saf his hondes twey
He slouȝ and alto rent the lyon
Toward his wedding walking bi the wey
His fals wif coude him so wel plese and prey
Til she his counseill knewe and she vntrewe
Vnto his foes his counseill gan be wreie
And him forsook / and took an other newe
One hundred foxes took Sampson for Ire
And al her tailes he to gider bonde
And set the foxes tailes al on fire
For he on eueri taill had knit a bronde
And they brent al the cornes in that londe
And al her Oliues and her vynes eke
A thousand men he slouȝ eke with his honde
And had no wepen but an asses cheke
Whan they were slain so thursted him that he
Was wel ny lorn for wich he gan to pray
That god wolde on his peine haue som pite
And sende him drink or ellis must he deye
And of this asses cheke that was drey
Out of a wang toth sprang anon a welle
Of wich he drank ynouȝ shortli for to sey
Thus halp him god as Iudicum can telle
By verri force at Gazan vpon a niȝt
Maulgre the Phisiciens of that cite
The gates of the toun he hath vp pliȝt
High on an hill where as men miȝt hem se .B.
And on his bak ycaried hem hath he .A.
O noble o miȝti Sampson lef and dere
Had thou nat tolde to wommen thi secre
In al this worlde ne had ben thi pere
This Sampson neuer sither drank ne wyn
Ne on his hed cam rasour non ne shere
By precept of the messanger diuine
For al his strengthes in his heres were
And fulli twenti winter there be yere
He had of Israell the gouernaunce
But sone shal he wepe many a tere
For wommen shul him bringe to mischaunce
Vnto his Lemman Dalida he tolde
That his strengthe all his strengthe lay
And falsli to his foo men she him solde
And sleping in hir barme vpon a day
She made to clippe or shere his here away
And made his foo men al his craft espien
And whan that they him founde in this array
They bonde him fast and put out his yhen
But or his here was clipped or I shaue
Ther was no bonde with wich men miȝt him bynde
But now is he in prison in a caue
Where as they made him at the querne grinde
O noble Sampson strengest of mankinde
O whilom Iuge in glory and richesse
Now maist thou wepe with thin yhen blinde
Sith thou from wele art falle in wrecchidnesse
The ende of his caitif was as I shal sey
His foomen made a feste vpon a day
And made him as her foole before hem pley
And this was in a temple of gret array
But ate last he made a foull affray
For he ij pilers shook ⁊ made hem falle
And doun fel temple and all there it lay
And slouȝ him self and eke his foo men alle
This is to sey the Princes euerichon
And eke thre thousand bodies were there slain
With falling of the gret temple of stoon
Of Sampson now I wol no more sein
Beth war be this ensample olde ⁊ plein
That noman telle her counseill to her wifes
Of such thinges as they wold haue secre fein
If that it touche her lymmes or her lifes
Of Hercules the souerain Conquerour
Singen his werkes loude ⁊ high renoun
For in his tyme of strengthe he was the flour
He slouȝ and rafte the skyn from the lyon
He of Centaures leid the boost adoun
He Arpies slouȝ the cruell birdes felle
He golden apples refte of the dragon
He drouȝ out of Cerberus the hound of helle
He slouȝ the cruel tirant Busyrus
And made his hors to frete him flessh ⁊ bon
He slouȝ the firy serpant venynyus
Of Achilous horne ij he brak oon
And he slouȝ Cacus in a caue of stoon
He slouȝ the geaunt Anthonus the stronge
He slouȝ the grisli boor and that anon
And bare the hed on his necke longe
Was neuer wiȝt sethen the world began
That slouȝ so many monstres as did he
Throuȝ out this wide world his name ran
What for his strengthe ⁊ his high bounte
And eueri Reme went he for to se
He was so strong that noman miȝt him lette
At bothe the worldes endes seith trophee
In stede of boundes he a piler sette
A lemman had this noble Champion
That hiȝt Deianire as fressh as may
And as these clerkes maken mencion
She hath him sent a sherte fressh ⁊ gay
Allas this sherte allas and wellaway
Enuenimed was so subtilli with all
That or he had wered it half a day
Hit made his flessh al from his bones falle
But natheles som clerkes her excusen
Be oon that hiȝt Nessus that it maked
Be as be may I wol hir nat accusen
But on his bak the sherte he wered al naked
Til that his flessh was for the venym blaked
And whan he saw non othir remedie
In hoot coles he hath him self raked
For with no venym deigneth him to dye
Thus starf this miȝti Hercules
Lo who may trust on fortune any throwe
For him that folowed al this world of pres
Or he be war is ofte I leid ful lowe
Ful wise is he that can him self knowe
Beth war for whan that fortune list to glose
Than waiteth she hir man to ouerthrowe
Be such aweye as he wolde lest suppose
The miȝti throne the precious tresour
The glorious septre and roiall mageste
That had the king Nabugadonasor
With tonge vnnethe may descriued be
He twies wan Iherusalem the cite
The vesselles of the temple he with him ladde
At Babiloigne was his souerain see
In wich his glorie and his delite he hadde
The fairest children of the blood roiall
Of Israel he lete gelde anon
And maked ech of hem to ben his thrall
Amonges othir Daniel was oon .
That was the wisest childe of euerichon
For he the dremes of the king expounded
Where as in Chaldeie clerk was ther non
That wist to what fyn his dremes souned
This proude king let make a statu of golde
Sexti cubites long and seuene in brede
To wich ymage be bothe yong and olde
Comaunded to loute and haue in drede
Or in a forneis full of flammes rede
He shal be brent that will nat obeye
But neuer wolde assent to that dede
Daniel ne his yong felawes tweye
This king of kinges proude was and elat
He went that god that sit in mageste
Ne miȝt him nat bereue of his estat
But sodeinli he lost his dignite
And lik a beeste him semed for to be
And ete hay as an oxe and lay theroute
In reyn with wilde bestes walked he
Til certein tyme was ycome aboute
And like an Egles fetheres wex his heres
His nailes lik a birdes clawes were
Til god relesed him a certain yeres
And yaf him witt and than with many a tere
He thanked god and euer his lif in fere
Was he to do amis or more trespace
And til that tyme he leid was on his bere
He knew that god was full of miȝt and grace
His sone wich that hiȝt Baltazar
That helde the regne aftir his fader day
He be his fader coude nat be war
For proude he was of herte and of array
And eke an Idolastre was he ay
His high estat assured him in pride
But fortune cast him doun ⁊ there he lay
And sodeinli his regne gan deuide
A feste he made vnto his lordes alle
Vpon a tyme and made hem blithe be
And than his officers gan he calle
Goth bringeth forth the vesselles quod he
Wich that my fader in his prosperite
Out of the temple of Iherusalem berafte
And to oure high goddes thank we
Of honour that oure elders with vs last
His wif his lordes and his concubines
Ay drunken while her appetite last
Out of these noble vesselles sondri wynes
And on a wall this King his yhen cast
And saw an hand armeles that wrot ful fast
For fere of wich he quook and sighed sore
This hande that Baltazar made so agast
Wrot . Mane . Techel . Phares . and nomore
In al that lond magicien was non
That coude expoune what this letter ment
But Daniel expouned / it anon
And seid king god to thi fader sent
Glorie and honour reyn tresour rent
And he was proude ⁊ nothing god ne dradde
And him beraft the regne that he hadde
He was out cast of mannes companie
With asses was his habitacion
And ete heye as a beste in wete ⁊ drie
Til that he knewe be grace and be reson
That god of heuen hath dominacion
Ouer eueri regne and eueri creature
And than had god of him compassion
And him restored his regne and his figure
Eke thou that art his sone art proude also
And knowest al these thinges verrili
And art rebell to god and art his foo
Thou eke drank of his vesselles boldely
Thi wif and thi wenches eke sinfulli
Drunk of the same vesselles sondri wynes
And heriest fals goddes cursedli
Therfor to the gret peine shapen is
This hand was sent from god that in the wall
Wrot Mane Techel Phares trust me
Thi reigne is doon thou weiest nat at all
Deuided is thi regne and it shal be
To Medes and Perces yȝouen quod he
And thilk same niȝt this king was slawe
And Darius occupieth his degre
Thouȝ he therto had nothir riȝt ne lawe
Lordinges examples herby mowe ye take
Hou that in lordship is no sikernesse
For whan fortune wol a man forsake
She bereth awey his regne and his richesse
And eke his frendes bothe more and lesse
For what man that hath frendes throuȝ fortune
Mishap wol make hem enmyes I gesse
The prouerbe is soth and full comune
Cenobia of Palymerie quene
As writen Persiens in her noblesse
So worthi was in armes ⁊ so kene
That no wiȝt passid hir in hardinesse
Ne in linage ne in othir gentilnesse
Of kinges blood of Peers is she descended
I sey nat she had most fairnesse
But of hir shap she miȝt nat ben amended
From hir childhod I finde that she fledde
Office of wommen and to wode she sent went
And many a wilde hertes blood she shedde
With arwes brode that she to hem sent
She was so swift that she anon hem hent
And whan that she was elder she wold kille
Lyons Leopardes and beres al to rent
And in her armes helde hem at her will
She durst wilde bestes dennes seke
And renne in the mountaines al the niȝt
And slepe vnder the bussh and she coude eke
Wrastle be verri force and verri miȝt
With any yong man were he neuer so wiȝt
Ther miȝt no thing in her armes stonde
She kepte her maidenhed from eueri wiȝt
To no man deined hir for to be bonde
But ate last her frendes han her maried
To Odenake a Prince of that contre
Al were it so that she hem long taried
And ye shul vnderstonde hou that he
Had such fantasies as had she
But natheles whan they were knit in fere
They lyued in ioye and in felicite
For ech of hem loued othir lef and dere
Saue oo thing that she wold neuer assent
Be no weye / that he shuld be hir lie
But ones for it was hir plein entent
To haue a childe the world to multeplie
And also sone as that she miȝt espie
That she was nat childe with that dede
Than wolde she suffre him don his fantasie
Eft sones . and nat but ones out of drede
And if she were with chide at that cast
Nomore shulde he pleie that game
Til fulli xl. dayes weren past
Than wolde she ones suffre him do the same
Al were this Odenake wilde or tame
He gate nomore of hir for thus she seide
It was to wifes leccherie and shame
In other caas if men with hem pleide
Tuo sones be this Odenake had she
The wich she kepte in vertu and lecture
But now vnto oure take torne we
I sey so worshipfull a creature
And wise ther with and large wtith mesure
So penible in the werre and curteis eke
Ne more labour miȝt in the werre endure
Was non / thouȝ al this world men shuld seke
Hir riche array ne miȝt nat be tolde
As wel in vessell as in her clothing
She was clad all in perry and in golde
And eke she left nat for non hunting
To haue of sondry tonges ful knowing
Whan that she leiser hade and to entende
To lerne bokes was her liking
Hou she in vertu hir lif miȝt dispende
And shortli of this story for to trete
So doubti was hir husbond and eke she
That they conquered many regnes grete
In the orient with many a fair cite
Appertenant vnto the mageste
Of Rome / and with strong hand helde hem ful fast
Ne neuer miȝt for foomen make hem fle
Ay whil that Odenakes daies laste
Her batailes who so list hem for to rede
Ayenst Sapor the king and othir moo
And hou that al this processe fil in dede
Whi she conquered / and what title therto
And aftir of hir mischef and hir woo
Hou that she was beseged and I take
Lat him vnto my mastir Petrak goo
That writeth Inouȝ of this I vndertake
Whan Odenake was ded she miȝtily
The regnes helde and with hir propre hond
Ayenst hir foes she fauȝt so cruelly
That there nas king ne Prince in al that Londe
That he nas glad if he that grace fonde
That she ne wolde vpon his londe werreie
With hir they made aliaunce be bonde
To ben in pees / and lete hir ride and pleye
Themperour of Rome Claudius
Ne him before the Romain galien
Ne durst neuer be so corageous
Ne non Ermyn ne non Egipcien
Ne Surrien ne non Arrabien
Within the felde that durst with hir fiȝt
Lest that she wolde with her hondes slen
Or with her meyne put hem to fliȝt
In Kinges habite went her sones tuo
As heires of her faders regnes alle
And Hermanno and Thimalao
Her names were as Perciens hem calle
But ay fortune hath in her hony galle
This miȝti quene may no while endure
Fortune out of hir regne made hir falle
To wrecchidnesse and to misauenture
Aurelian whan that the gouernaunce
Of Rome / cam in to his hondes tweie
He shope vpon this quene to do vengeaunce
And with his legions he took his weie
Toward Cenobie and shortli forto seie
He made hir fle and ate last hir hent
And fetred hir and eke hir childern tweie
And wan the lond and hom to Rome he went
Amonges othir thinges that he wan
Hir chaire that wrouȝt with gold was and perre
This grete Romain this Aurelian
Hath with him lad for that men shuld it se
Before his triumphe walketh she
With gilt cheines on hir necke hanging
Corouned was as after her degre
And full of perre charged hir clothing
Allas fortune she that whilom was
Dredefull to kinges / ⁊ to Emperours
Now gawreth on hir al the people allas
And she that helmed was in stark stoures
And be force wan tounes strong ⁊ toures
Shal on hir hed were a vitrimite
And she that bar the septre full of floures
Shal bere a distaf hir cost for to quite
Al thouȝ that Nero were vicious
As any feend that lieth ful lowe doun
Yit he as tellith vs Swethoneus
This wide world had in subiection
Bethe est and west North and Semptemtrioūn
Of Rubies Saphirs and of perles white
Were al his clothes broided vp and doun
For he in gemmes gretli gan delite
More delicat more pompous of array
More proude was neuer Emperour than he
That ilke cloth that he had worn o day
Aftir that tyme he nolde it neuer se
Nettes of gold thred had he gret plente
To fisshe in Tibre whan him list to pleie
His lustes were as lawe in his degre
For fortune as his frende wold him obeye
He Rome brent for his delicacie
The Senatours he slouȝ vpon a day
To hiere hou that man wold wepe and crie
And slouȝ his brothir and be his suster lay
His moder made he in pitous array
For he hir wombe did slitte to be holde
Where he conceiued was so wealaway
That he so litill of his moder tolde
No tere out of his yhen for that siȝt
Ne com / but seid a faire womman was she
Gret wonder is hou that he coude or miȝt
Be domesman of hir ded beaute
The wyn to bringe him comaunded he
And drank anon / non othir woo he made
Whan miȝt is ioyned vnto cruelte
Allas to depe woll the venym wade
In youthe a master had this Emperour
To teche him lecture and curtesie
For of moralte he was the flour
As in his tyme but if bookes lye
And whill this mastir had of him mastrie
He maked him so conning ⁊ so souple
That long tyme it was or that tirannie
Or any vice durst in him vncouple
Thilk Seneca of wich that I deuise
Be cause Nero had him in such drede
For he from vices wol him alwey chastise
Discretli as be word and nat be dede
Sir wolde he sey am Emperour must nede
Be vertuous . and hate tirannie
For wich he in a bath made him to blede
On bothe his armes til he must deye
This Nero had eke of a custumaunce
In youthe ayenst his master for to rise
Wich aftirward him thouȝt a gret greuaunce
Therfor he made him dyen in this wise
But natheles this Seneca this wise
Chace in a bath to dye in this maner
Rather than haue an other tormentrie
And thus hath Nero slain his mastir dere
Now fel it so that fortune list no lenger
The high pride of Nero to cherisshe
For thouȝ that he was strong yit was she strenger
She thouȝt thus be god I am to nice
To set / a man that is fulfilled of vice
In high degre / and Emperour him calle
Be god out of his seete I wol him trice
Whan he lest weneth sonnest shal he falle
The people ros vpon him on a niȝt
For his defaulte / and whan he it espied
Out at his dores anon he hath him diȝt
Alone / and there he wende ha ben allied
He knokked fast and ay the more he cried
The faster shet they her dores alle
Tho wist he wel he had him self misguied
And went his weye no lenger durst he calle
The people cried and rombled vp and doun
That with his eres herd he hou they seide
Where is this fals Tirant this Neroun
For fere almost out of his wit he breid
And to his goddes pitousli he preide
For socour / but it miȝt nat betide
For drede of this him thouȝt that he deide
And ran in to a gardyn him to hide
And in this gardin fonde he cherles twey
That saten be a fire gret and red
And to these cherles he gan to prey
To slen him and to girde of his hed
That to his body whan that he were ded
Were no despite ydon for his diffame
Him self he slouȝ he coude no better rede
Of wich fortune lough and had a game
Was neuer Capitaigne vnder a King
That reignes moo put in subiection
Ne strenger was in feld of all thing
As in his tyme ne gretter of renoun
Ne more pompous in high presumpioūn
Than Oleferne wich fortune ay kist
So likerousli and led him vp and doun
Til that his hed was of or that he wist
Nat onli that this world had him in awe
For lesing of richesse or liberte
But made eueri man reneye his lawe
Nabugadonosor was god seid he
Non othir god shulde honoured be
Ayenst this heest no wiȝt dar trespace
Saf in Bethulia a strang cite
Where Eliachim a prest was of that place
But take kepe of the deth of Oloferne
Amid his hoost he drunke lay al niȝt
Within his tente large as is a berne
And yit for all his pompe ⁊ al his miȝt
Iudith a womman as he lay vpriȝt
Sleping his hed of smot and from his tente
Ful priueli she stale from eueri wiȝt
And with his hed vnto hir toun she wente
What nedith it of King Antiochus
To telle his high roiall mageste
His high pride his werkes venemous
For such an othir was ther non as he
Rede what he was he was in Machabe
And rede the pride that he seide
And whi he fell from high prosperite
And in a hill hou wrecchidli he deyde
Fortune him had enhaunced so in pride
That verrili he wende he miȝt atteine
Vnto the sterres vpon eueri side
And in a balaunce were ech mountaine
And al the floodes of the see to restreine
And goddes people had he most in hate
Hem wolde he sle in tornement and peine
Wening that god ne miȝt his pride abate
And for that Nichamor and Tymothee
With Iewes venquisshed miȝtly
Vnto the Iewes such an hate had he
That he bad gete his chare ful hastely
And swore and seid full despitously
Vnto Iherusalem he wolde eft sone
To wreke his Ire on it ful cruelly
But of his purpos he was let ful sone
God for his manace him so sore smot
With vnuisible wounde ay vncurable
That in his guttes carf it so and boot
That his peines were importable
And certainli the wrecche was but resonable
For many a mannes guttes did he peine
But from his purpos cursed and dampnable
But bade anon apparailen his hoost
And sodeinli or he were of it war
God daunted all his pride and bost
For he so sore fell out of his chare
That it his lymmes and his skyn to tare
So that he miȝt neither go ne ride
But in a chare men aboute him bare
Al forbrosed bothe bak and side
The wreche of god smot him so cruelly
That throuȝ his body wicked wormes crepte
And there with all he stank so horrible
That non of al his meyne that him kepte
Whethir so he wook or ellis he slepte
They miȝt nat the stink of him endure
In this mischef he wailed eke and wepte
And knewe god lord ouer eueri creature
To al his hoost and to him self also
Ful lothsom was the stink of his carein
No man ne miȝt him bere to ne fro
And in this stink and this horrible peine
He starf full wrecchidli in a mountaine
Thus hath this Robbour and this homicide
That many a man made to wepe and pleine
Such guerdon as belongeth vnto pride
The story of Alisaunder is so comune
That eueri wiȝt that hath discrecion
Hath herd somwhat or all of his fortune
This wide worlde as in conclusioūn
He wan be strengthe or for his high renoun
They were glad for pees vnto him sende
The pride of man ⁊ beste he leid adoun
Where so he cam vnto the worldes ende
Comparison miȝt neuer yit be maked
Betuen him and an othir conquerour
For al this worlde for drede of him hath quaked
He of kniȝthod and of fredam flour
Saue wyn ⁊ wommen ne thing miȝt aswage
His high entent in armes and labour
Fortune him the heir maked of hir honour
So was he full of Leonyn corage
What pris were it to him thouȝ I tolde
Of Darius and of an C. thousand moo
Of Kinges Princes dukes Erles bolde
Wich he conquered and brouȝt hem in to woo
I sey as fer as man may ride or goo
The worlde was his what shulde I more deuise
For thouȝ I write and tolde you euer mo
Of his kniȝthod it miȝt nat suffise
Xij he regned as seith Machabee
Philip his sone of Macedonie he was
That first was king in Grece the contre
O worthi gentill Alisaunder allas
That euer shuld falle such a caas
Enpoisouned of thin ougne folk thou were
Thi Sys fortune hath torned in to Aas
For the ne she wepeth neuer a tere
Who shal me yeue teres to compleine
The deth of gentillesse and of fraunchise
That al this world welded in his demeyne
And yit him thouȝt it miȝt nat suffise
So full was his corage of high emprise
Allas who shal me helpe to endite
Fals fortune and poison to despise
The wich tuo of al this woo I wite
Be wisdam manhod and be gret labour
From humble heed vnto roiall mageste
Vp ros he Iulius the Conquerour
That wan all Occident be londe and See
Be strengthe of hond orellis be trete
And vnto Rome made hem tributarie
And sith of Rome themperour was he
Til that fortune wex his aduersarie
O miȝti Cesar that in Thessalie
Ayenst Pompeius fader thin in lawe
That of the orient had al the chiualrie
As fer as that the day beginneth to dawe
Thou throuȝ thi kniȝthod hast hem take and slawe
Saue fewe folk that with pompeius fledde
Throuȝ wich thou puttest all thorient in awe
Thank fortune that so wel the spedde
But now a litill while I will bewaile
This Pompeius this noble gouernour
Of Rome wich that fley at this bataill
I sey oon of his men a fals Traitour
His hed of smot to winne him fauour
Of Iulius . and him the hed he brouȝt
Allas Pompeie of thorient conquerour
That fortune vnto such a fyn the brouȝt
To Rome ayein repaireth Iulius
With his triumphe laureat ful high
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius
That euer had of his estat enuie
Ful priueli hath made conspiracie
Ayenst this Iulius in subtill wise
And cast the place in wich he shuld dye
With boydekynes as I shal you deuise
This Iuliu to the Capitoill went
Vpon a day as he was wont to gon
And in the Capitoill him hent
This fals Brutus and his other foon
And stiked him with Boidekynes anon
With many a wounde ⁊ thus they lete him lye
But neuer stro grunt he at no strok but oon
Orellis at tuo but if his storie lye
So manli was this Iulius of his herte
And so wel he loued estatli honeste
That thouȝ his dedli woundes so sore smert
His mantell ouer his hippes cast he
For noman shuld se his priuete
And as he lay a dying in a traunce
And wist verrili that ded was he
Of honeste / yit had he remembraunce
Lucan to the this story I recomende
And to Sweton and to Valerius also
That of the story writen word and ende
Hou that these grete Conquerours tuo
Fortune was first frend and sith a foo
No man ne trust of fortune fauour longe
But haue hir in a waite for euermo
Witnesse on alle these conquerous stronge
This riche Cresus whilom king of Lyde
Of wich Cresus Cirus sore him dradde
Yit was he cauȝt amiddes all his pride
And to be brent men to the fire him lad
But such a rein doun from the walken shad
That it slouȝ the fire and made it to escape
But to be war no grace yit he had
Til fortune on the galwes made him gape
Whan he escaped was he can nat stinte
But he began a newe werre agein
He wend wel / for that fortune him sent
Such hap that he escaped throuȝ the rein
That of his foes he miȝt nat be slein
And eke a sweuene on a niȝt he mette
Of wich he was so proude and eke so fein
That in vengeaunce al his herte sette
Vpon a tre he was as that him thouȝte
Where Iubiter him wissh bothe bak and side
And Phebus eke a fair towaill him brouȝt
To drie him with / and herfore wex his pride
And to his douȝter that stood him beside
Wich that he knewe in high science habounde
He bad hir telle him what it signefied
And she riȝt thus his dreme began expounde
The tree quod she the galwes is to mene
And Iubiter betokeneth snow and rein
And Phebus with his towaill so clene
Tho ben the sonne stremes for to sein
Thou shalt an hanged be fader certein
Reyn shal the wasshe ⁊ sonne shal the drie
Thus warned him full plat and ful plein
His douȝter wich that callid was Phanye
Anhanged was Cresus the proude King
His roial throne miȝt him nouȝt availl
Tragedies non othir maner thing
Ne can in singing crie ne bewaile
But that fortune al day wold assaill
With vnwar strok the regnes that ben proude
For whan men trust hir than wol she faill
And couere hir briȝt face with a cloude
O noble o worthi Petre glory of Spaine
Whan fortune heeld so high mageste
Wel ouȝt men thi pitous deth compleine
Out of thi lond thi brothir made the fle
And aftir at a Siege be subtilite
Ye there bothe tuo to gider went
Where as with his ougne hond slouȝ the
Succeding in thi regne ⁊ in thi rent
The felde of snow with the Egle therin
Cauȝt with the lymerod coloured as the glade
He breweth this cursidnesse ⁊ al this sinne
The wicked nest was werker of this nede
Nouȝt Charles ne Oliuer that took ay hede
Of trouthe and honour but of Armorik
Genylon / Olyuer corrupt for mede
Brouȝt this worthi Kniȝt in such a brike
O worthi Petro King of Cipre also
That Alisaunder wan be high maistrie
Ful many an hethen wrouȝtest thou woo
Of wich thin ougne lieges haden enuie
And for no thing but for thi chiualrie
They in thi bedde han slein the bi the morwe
Thus can fortune hir whele gouerne ⁊ guie
And out of Ioye bringe men to sorwe
Of Melan gret Barnabo Viscount
God of delite and scorge of Lumbardie
Whi shuld I nat thin infortune account
Sith in estat thou clombe were so highe
Thi brothers sone that was thi double allie
For he thi Neoveu was and sone in lawe
Within his prison made the to dye
But whi / ne hou not I that thou were slawe
Of the Erle Hughelyn of Pise the languor
There may no tunge telle for pite
But litill out of Pise stant a tour
In wich p tour in prison was he
And with him ben his litill children iij
The eldest scarsli was v. yere of age
Allas fortune it was gret cruelte
Such birdes to put in such a cage
Dampned was he to dye in that prison
For Roger wich that busshop was of pise
Hade on him made a fals suggestion
Throuȝ wich the people gan vpon hem rise
And putten him to prison in such awise
As ye han herd and mete ⁊ drink he hadde
So small . that wel vnnethe it may suffise
And there with all it was ful poore and badde
And on a day befell that in that houre
Whan that his mete wont was to be brouȝt
The Gayler shet the dores of the Tour
He herd it wel but he spak riȝt nouȝt
And in his herte anon ther fill a thouȝt
That they for hunger wold don him dyen
Allas quod he allas that I was wrouȝt
Ther with the teres fel from his yhen
His yong sone that iij yere was of age
Vnto him seide fader fader whi do ye wepe
Whan wol the Gailer bring oure potage
Is ther no morsell bred that ye do kepe
I am so hungri that I may nat slepe
Now wold god that I miȝt slepe euer
Than shuld nat hunger in my wombe crepe
There is no thing but drede that me were leuer
Thus day be day this child began to crie
Til in his faders barme adoun it lay
And seid farwel fader for I mot dye
And kist his fader and dyed the same day
And whan the wofull fader ded it say
For woo his armes tuo he gan to bite
And seid allas fortune and welaway
Thi fals wheell my woo I may al wite
His children wende that it for hunger was
That he his armes gnew and nat for woo
And seiden fader do nat so allas
But rather ete the flessh vpon vs tuo
Oure flessh thou yaue vs / take oure flessh vs fro
And ete ynouȝ riȝt thus they to him seide
And aftir that within a day or tuo
They leide hem in his lappe and deide
Him self dispeired for hunger starf
Thus ended is this miȝti Erle of pise
From hiȝ estat fortune awey hath carf
Of this Tragedie it ouȝt I now suffise
Who so wol hiere it in a lenger wise
Redeth the gret Poete of Itaill
That hiȝt Daunt for he can it wel deuise
From point to point nat oo word wol he faill .

Ho quod the kniȝt gode
Sir nomore of this .

Than ye han
seid is riȝt Inouȝ Iwys .

And moch more
for litil heuinesse /
Is riȝt Inouȝ for moch folk I gesse
I sey for me it is a gret disease
Where as men haue ben in gret welthe ⁊ ease
To hiere of her sodein fall allas
And the contrarie is ioye and solas
As whan a man hath ben in poore estat
And clymbeth vp and wexeth fortunat
And there abideth in prosperite
Such thing is gladsom as thinketh me
And of som thing were goodli for to telle
Ye quod oure oost be Seint Poules belle
Ye sey riȝt thus this monk he clappeth loude
He spak hou fortune was couered with a cloude
I wot neuer what and als of Tragedie
Riȝt now ye herd and parde no remedie
Is it for to be wailen ne compleine
That that is don / and also it is a peine
As he han seid to hiere of heuinesse
Sir monk no more of this so god you blesse
Your tale annoieth al this companie
Such thing is not worth a bottyrflie
For ther is no chere disport ne game
Wherfor Sir Monk O daun Piers be thi name
I pray you hertly telles vs somwhat elles
For sekirli ner clinking of your belles
That on your bridel hang on eueri side
By heuen king that for vs alle dyde
I shuld or this ha falle doun for slepe
Al thouȝ the slouȝ had neuer be so depe
Than hade your tale al be tolde in vein
For certainli as these clerkes sein
Where as a man may haue non audience
Nat te helpeth it to telle his sentence
And wel I wot the substaunce is in me
If any thing shal wel reported be
Sir sey somwhat of hunting I you pray
Nay quod this Monke I haue no lust to play
Now let an othir telle as I haue tolde
Than spak oure oost with rude speche ⁊ bolde
And seid vnto the Nonnes prest anon
Com ner prest com hider thou Sir Iohn
Telle vs such thing as may oure hertes glade
Be blithe thouȝ thou ride vpon a Iade
What thouȝ thin hors be bothe foule ⁊ lene
If he wil serue the rek nat a bene
Loke that thin hert be mery euermo
Yis sir quod he / yis hoost so mot I goo
But I be mery I wis I wil be blamed
And riȝt anon his tale he hath attamed
And thus he seid to vs euerichon
This swete prest this goodli man Sir Iohn

A pore wudewe som del stope in age
Was whilom duelling in a narwe cotage
Beside a groue standing in a dale
This widewe of wich I telle you my tale
Syn thilk day that she was last a wif
In pacience led a simple lif
For litil was hir catell and hir rent
By husbondrie of wich as god hir sent
She fonde hir seluen and eke douȝtern tuo
Thre large sowes had she and no mo
Thre keen and eke a sheep that hiȝt malle
Ful soty was hir boure and eke hir halle
In wich she ete ful many a slender mele
Of poinant sauce knewe she neuer a deell
No deinte morsell passid throuȝ hir throte
Hir diet was according to hir cote
Replexion ne made hir neuer seke
Attempre diet was all hir phisik
And excercise and hertli suffisaunce
The goute lettid hir nouȝt for to daunce
No wyn drank she neither white ne dred
Ne Apoplexie shent neuer hir hed
Hir borde was serued most with white ⁊ blak
Milk and broun bred in wich she fonde no lak
Seind bacon and somtime an eye or twey
For she was as it were a maner deye
A yerd she had enclosed al aboute
With stickes and a drie diche withoute
In wich she had a cok hiȝt Chauntcler
In al that lond of crowing nas his pere
His vois was merier than the mery orgon
On massedaies that in chirche goon
Wel sikerer was his crowing in his logge
Than is a clok or any Abbeies orlogge
Be nature he knew ech assencion
Of thequinoxiall in that toun
For whan degrees xv were ascended
Than crue he that it miȝt nat be amended
His combe was redder than the fyne corall
And batailled as it were a castell wall
His bill was blak and as the geet it shon
Lyk Asure were his leggis and his toon
His nailes whitter than the lilly flour
And lik the burned gold was his colour
This gentil cok had in his gouernaunce
Vij hennes for to do al his plesaunce

(base) For ye that knowen wel oure Innocence
(base) For as muche as we doon a reuerence
(base) To crist and for we bere a cristen name
(base) Ye putte on vs a cryme and eek a blame
(base) But we that knowen thilke name so
(base) For vertuous we may it nat withseye
(base) Almache answerde chees oon of thise two
(base) Do sacrifice or cristendom reneye
(base) That thow mowe now escapen by that weye
(base) At which this holy blisful faire mayde
(base) Gan for to laughe and to the Iuge she sayde
(base) O Iuge confus in thy nycetee
(base) Wiltow that I reneye Innocence
(base) To maken me a wikked wight quod she
(base) Lo he dissimuleth heere in audience
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) He stareth and woodeth in his aduertence
(base) To whom Almachius vnsely wrecche
(base) Ne wostow nat how fer my myght may strecche
(base) Han noght oure myghty princes to me yeuen
(base) Ye bothe power and auctoritee
(base) To maken folk to dyen or to lyuen
(base) Why spekestow so prowdly thanne to me
(base) I speke noght but stedefastly quod she
(base) Nat proudly for I seye as for my syde
(base) We haten dedly thilke vice of pryde
(base) And if thow drede nat a sooth to here
(base) Thanne wol I shewe al openly by right
(base) That thow hast maad a ful greet lesyng here
(base) Thow seist thy princes han thee yeuen myght
(base) Bothe for to sleen and for to quyken a wight
(base) Thow that ne mayst but oonly lyf byreue
(base) Thow hast noon oother power ne no leue
(base) But thow mayst seyn thy princes han thee maked
(base) Ministre of deeth for if thow speke of me
(base) Thow lyest for thy power is ful naked
(base) Do wey thy boldnesse seyde Almachius tho
(base) And sacrifice to oure goddes er thow go
(base) I recche nat what wrong that thow me profre
(base) For I kan suffre it as a Philosophre
(base) But thilke wronges may I nat endure
(base) That thow spekest of oure goddes here quod he
(base) Cecilie answerde o nyce creature
(base) Thow seydest no word syn thow spak to me
(base) That I ne knew therwith thy nycetee
(base) And that thow were in euery maner wise
(base) A lewed Officer a veyn Iustise
(base) Ther lakketh no thyng to thyne outter eyen
(base) That thow nart blynd for thyng that we seen alle
(base) That is a stoon that men may wel espien
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That ilke stoon a god thow wolt it calle
(base) I rede thee lat thyn hand vpon it falle
(base) And taste it wel and stoon thow shalt it fynde
(base) Syn that thow seest nat with thyne eyen blynde
(base) It is a shame that the peple shal
(base) So scornen thee and laughe at thy folye
(base) For comenly men woot it wel oueral
(base) That myghty god is in hise heuenes hye
(base) And thise ymages wel thow mayst espye
(base) To thee ne to hem self mowe noght profite
(base) For in effect they be nat worth a myte
(base) Thise and swiche othere seyde she
(base) And he weex wrooth and bad men sholde hir lede
(base) Hoom til hir hous and in hir hous quod he
(base) Bren hire right in a Bath of flambes rede
(base) And as he bad right so was doon the dede
(base) For in a Bath they gonne hire faste shetten
(base) And nyght and day greet fyr they vnder betten
(base) The longe nyght and eek a day also
(base) For al the fyr and eek the Bathes hete
(base) She sat al coold and feeled no wo
(base) It made hir nat o drope for to swete
(base) But in that Bath hir lyf she moste lete
(base) For he Almachius with a ful wikke entente
(base) To sleen hire in the Bath his sonde sente
(base) Thre strokes in the nekke he smoot hire tho
(base) The tormentour but for no maner chaunce
(base) He myghte noght smyte al hir nekke atwo
(base) And for ther was that tyme an ordinaunce
(base) That no man sholde doon man swich penaunce
(base) The ferthe strook to smyten softe or soore
(base) This tormentour ne dorste do namoore
(base) But half deed with hir nekke ycoruen there
(base) He lefte hir lye and on his wey he went
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The cristen folk whiche that aboute hire were
(base) With shetes han the blood ful faire yhent
(base) Thre dayes lyued she in this torment
(base) And neuere cessed hem the feith to teche
(base) That she hadde fostred hem she gan to preche
(base) And hem she yaf hir moebles and hir thyng
(base) And to the Pope Vrban bitook hem tho
(base) And seyde I axed this of heuene kyng
(base) To han respit thre dayes and namo
(base) To recommende to yow er that I go
(base) Thise soules lo and that I myghte do Werche
(base) Here of myn hous perpetuelly a cherche
(base) Seint Vrban with hise deknes pryuely
(base) The body fette and buryed it by nyghte
(base) Among hise othere Seintes honestly
(base) Hir hous the chirche of Seinte Cecilie highte
(base) Seint Vrban halwed it as he wel myghte
(base) In which in to this day in noble wyse
(base) Men doon to crist and to his Seinte seruyse
[This line not in the base text]
(base) ¶ hic incipit fabula
(base) Whan ended was the lyf of seint Cecile
(base) Er we fully hadde ryden fyue myle
(base) At Boghtoun vnder the blee . vs gan atake /
(base) A man that clothed was in clothes blake
(base) And vnder that he hadde a whit surplys
(base) His hakeney that was al pomel grys
(base) So swette that it wonder was to see
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) It semed he hadde priked myles thre
(base) Aboute the peytrel stood the foom ful hiȝe
(base) He was of fome al flekked as a pye
(base) The hors eek that his ȝoman rood vpon
(base) So swette that vnnethe mighte he gon
(base) A male twyfold on his croper lay
(base) It semed that he caryed lytel aray
(base) Al light for somer rood this worthy man
(base) And in myn herte wondren I bygan
(base) What that he was til that I vnderstood
(base) How that his cloke was sewed to his hood
(base) For which whan I longe hadde avised me /
(base) I demed him som chanoun for to be /
(base) His hat hyng at his bak doun by a las /
(base) For he hadde ryde more than trot or pas /
(base) He hadde ay priked lyk as he were wood
(base) A clote leef he hadde vnder his hood
(base) For swot and for to kepe his heed from hete
(base) But it was ioye for to seen him swete /
(base) His forhed dropped as a stillatorie
(base) Were ful of plaunteyne and of peritorie
(base) And whan that he cam he bigan to crye
(base) God saue quod he this Ioly companye
(base) His ȝoman eek was ful of curtesye
(base) And sires now in the morwe tyde /
(base) Out of ȝoure ostellerye I sayz ȝou ryde
(base) And warned heer my lord and my souerayn
(base) Which that to ryde with ȝou is ful fayn
(base) For his disport he loueth daliaunce
(base) Frend for thy warnyng god ȝiue the good chaunce
(base) Faste haue I priked quod he for ȝoure sake
(base) Ful faste you to ouertake
(base) But yit I pray the for goddis sake
(base) Sayde oure oost certes it wolde seeme /
(base) Thy lord were wys and so I may wel deme
(base) He is ful iocunde also dar I lay
(base) Kan he ought telle a merye tale or tway
(base) With which he glade may this companye
(base) Who sire my lord ; ȝe ȝe withoute lye /
(base) He can of merthe and eek of Iolite
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Nought but ynough also sire trusteth to me
(base) And ȝe him knewe als wel as do I
(base) Ȝe wolde wondre how wel and thriftyly
(base) He couthe werke and that in sondry wyse
(base) He hath take on him many sondry aprise
(base) Which were ful hard for eny that is heere /
(base) To bringe aboute but they of him it lere
(base) As homely as he ryt amonges ȝou
(base) If ȝe him knewe it wolde be ȝoure prow /
(base) Ȝe nolde not forgon his aqueintance
(base) For mochil good I dar leye in balaunce
(base) Al that I haue my possessioun
(base) He is a man of heigh discrecioun
(base) I warne ȝou wel he is a passynge man
(base) Wel quoth oure host I pray the telle me than
(base) Is he a Clerk or noon tell what he is
(base) Nay he is gretter than a clerk y wys
(base) Seyde the ȝoman and in wordes fewe
(base) Oft and of his craft somwhat I wol ȝou schewe
(base) I say my lord can such a sotilte
(base) But all his crafte ȝe may not wite at me
(base) And somwhat helpe I ȝit to his worchinge
(base) That al this ground which that we ben on rydynge
(base) Til that we come to Caunturbury toun
(base) He couthe al clene turne it vp se doun
(base) And paue it al of siluer and of gold
(base) And whan this ȝoman hadde thus y told
(base) Vnto oure //hoost he seyde benedicite
(base) This thing is wonder merueylous to me /
(base) Sithens that thi lord is of so heigh prudence /
(base) By cause of which men scholde him reuerence /
(base) That of his worschipe rekketh he so lyte
(base) His ouer sloppe nys nouȝt worth a myte /
(base) As in effecte to him so mote I go
(base) It is al baudy and to tore also
(base) Whi is thi lord so sluttissche I the prey
(base) And is of power better clothes to bey
(base) If that his dede acorde with thy speche
(base) Tell me that and that I the byseche /
(base) Why quod this ȝeman wherto aske ȝe me /
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) God help me so for he schal neuer y the
(base) But I wol not avowe that I say
(base) And therfore kepe it secre I ȝou pray
(base) He is to wys in faith as I bileeue
(base) And that is ouer doon it nyl not preue
(base) And right as clerkes sein it is a vice
(base) Wherfore in that I holde him lewed and nyce
(base) For whan a ma hath ouer gret a witt
(base) Ful often it happeth to mysvsen it
(base) So doth my lord and that me greueth sore
(base) God it amende I can seye now no more
(base) Ther of no fors goode ȝoman quod oure hoost
(base) Sithens of the connyng of thy lord thou woost
(base) Tell how he doth I pray the hertely
(base) Sithens that he is so crafty and so sly
(base) Wher dwellen ȝe if to telle be
(base) In subarbes of a toun quod he
(base) Lurkyng in hernes and in lanes blynde
(base) Where thise Robbers and theeues be kynde
(base) Holden here preuy ferful resydence
(base) As thay that dur nat schewe here presence
(base) So fare we if I schal saye the sothe
(base) Ȝit quod oure hoste lat me talke tothe
(base) Why art thou discoloured on thy face
(base) Peter quod he god ȝiue hit harde grace
(base) I am so vsed in the fyre to blowe
(base) That it hath chaunged my colour as I trowe
(base) I nam nat wont in myrour to prye
(base) But swynke sore and lerne to multiplye
(base) We bloundren euer and pouren in the fyr
(base) And for al that we faillen of oure desir
(base) For euer we lacken oure conclusioun
(base) To moche folk we ben but Illusioun
(base) And borwe gold be it a pound or tuo
(base) Or ten or twelue or manye sommes mo
(base) And make hem wenen atte leste weye
(base) That of a pound we couthe make tweye
(base) Ȝit is it fals and ay we han good hope
(base) It for to don and after it we grope
(base) But that science is so fer vs biforn
(base) We mowe not although we hadde it sworn
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) It ouertake it slyt awey so faste
(base) It wole us make beggeres atte laste
(base) Whil this ȝoman was thus in this talking
(base) This chanoun drough him ner and herde all thing
(base) Which that this ȝoman spak for suspecioun
(base) Of mennes speche euere hadde this Chanoun
(base) For Catoun seith he that gulty is
(base) Demeth all thing be spoke of him ywys
(base) By cause of that he gan so neigh to drawe /
(base) His ȝoman that he herde all his sawe /
(base) And thus he sayde vnto his ȝoman tho
(base) Holde now thy pees and speke wordes no mo /
(base) For if thou dost thou schalt it dere abye
(base) Thou sclaundrest me here in this compaignye
(base) And eek discouerest that thou scholdest hyde
(base) Ȝee quod oure hoost / telle on what so betyde
(base) Of all this thretyng recche I nat a myte
(base) I faith quod he no more do I but a lite
(base) And whan this Chanoun say it wolde nat be
(base) But his ȝoman wolde telle his priuyte
(base) He fledde awey for verray sorwe and schame /
(base) A quod the ȝoman here schal aryse a game
(base) Al that I can anon right wol I telle
(base) Sithens he is gon the foule feend him quelle /
(base) For neuer her after wol I with him mete
(base) For peny ne for pound I ȝou biheete /
(base) He that me broughte ferst vnto that game /
(base) Er that he deye sorwe haue he and schame
(base) For it is ernest to me by my fayth
(base) So shal he finde for sothe that it assaieth
(base) And ȝit for al my smert and al my greef
(base) For al my sorwe labour and mescheef
(base) I couthe neuer leue it in no wyse
(base) Now wolde god my witt mighte suffise
(base) To tellen al that longeth to that art
(base) But napeles ȝit wol I telle a part
(base) Sythens that my lord is gon I wol not spare
(base) Such thing as I knowe I wol declare /
(base) ¶ Heere endeþ þe prologe of the Chanouns Yemannes tale ~

div.l: (base) With this Chanoun / I dwelt haue seuen yeer
(base) And of his science / am I neuer the neer
(base) Al that I hadde / I haue lost ther by
(base) And god woot so hath many mo than I
(base) Ther I was wont to be right fressh and gay
(base) Of clothyng and of oother good array
(base) Now may I were / an hose vp on myn heed
(base) And wher my colour / was bothe fressh and reed
(base) Now is it wan / and of leden hewe
(base) Who so it vseth / soore shal he rewe
(base) And of my swynk / yet blered is myn eye
(base) Lo / which auantage / is to multiplie
(base) That slidynge science / hath me maad so bare
(base) That I haue no good / wher that euere I fare
(base) And yet I am endetted so ther by
(base) Of gold / that I haue borwed trewely
(base) That whil I lyue / I shal it quite neuere
(base) Lat euery man be war by me for euere
(base) What maner man / that casteth hym therto
(base) If he continue / I holde his thrift y do
(base) For so help me god / ther by shal he nat wynne
(base) But empte his purs / and make hise wittes thynne
(base) And whan he / thurgh his madnesse and folye
(base) Hath lost his owene good / thurgh Iupertye
(base) Thanne he exciteth / oother folk / ther to
(base) To lesen hir good / as he hym self hath do
(base) For vn to shrewes / ioye it is and ese
(base) To haue hir felawes / in peyne and disese
(base) Thus was I / ones lerned of a Clerk
(base) Of that no charge / I wol speke of oure werk
(base) ¶ Whan we been there / as we shul excercise
(base) Oure Eluysshe craft / we semen wonder wise
(base) Oure termes / been so clergial / and so queynte
(base) I blowe the fir / til that myn herte feynte
(base) What sholde I tellen ech proporcioun
(base) Of thynges / whiche that we werche vpon
(base) As on fyue / or sixe Ounces / may wel be
(base) Of siluer / or som oother quantitee
(base) And bisye me / to telle yow the names
(base) Of Orpyment brent bones / Iren Squames
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That in to poudre grounden been ful smal
(base) And in an erthen pot put is al
(base) And salt yput In / and also papeer
(base) Biforn thise poudres / that I speke of heer
(base) And wel ycouered / with a lampe of glas
(base) And muchel oother thyng which that ther was
(base) And of the pot and glasses enlutyng
(base) That of the Eyr myghte passe out no thyng
(base) And of the esy fir / and smart also
(base) Which that was maad / and of the care and wo
(base) That we hadden / in oure matires sublymyng /
(base) And in almalgamyng and calcemyng /
(base) And of quyk siluer / yclept Mercurie crude
(base) For alle oure sleightes / we kan nat conclude
(base) Oure Orpyment . and sublymed Mercurie
(base) Oure grounden litarge eek in the Prfurie
(base) Of ech of thise / of Ounces a certeyn
(base) Noght helpeth vs / oure labour is in veyn
(base) Ne eek oure spirites Ascencioun
(base) Ne oure matires / that lyen al fix adoun
(base) Mowe in oure werkyng no thyng vs auaille
(base) For lost is / al oure labour and trauaille
(base) And al the cost a twenty deuel way
(base) Is lost also / which we vp on it lay
(base) ¶ Ther is also / ful many another thyng
(base) That is / vn to oure craft apertenyng /
(base) Though I by ordre / hem nat reherce kan
(base) By cause / that I am a lewed man
(base) Yet wol I telle hem / as they come to mynde
(base) Thogh I ne kan nat sette hem in hir kynde
(base) As Boole Armonyak vertgrees / Boras
(base) And sondry vessels / maad of erthe and glas
(base) Oure vrynals / and oure descensories
(base) Violes / crosletz / and Sublymatories
(base) Cucurbites / and Alambikes eek
(base) And othere swiche / deere ynough a leek
(base) Nat nedeth it for to reherce hem alle
(base) Watres rubifiyng and Boles galle
(base) Arsenyk / sal Armonyak and Brymstoon
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And herbes / koude I telle eek many oon
(base) As Egremoyne / Valerian / and Lunarie
(base) And othere swiche / if that me liste tarie
(base) Oure lampes brennyng bothe nyght and day
(base) To brynge aboute / oure purpos / if we may
(base) Oure fourneys eek / of Calcinacioun
(base) And of watres Albificacioun
(base) Vnslekked lym / Chalk / and gleyre of an ey
(base) Poudres diuerse / asshes / donge / pisse / and cley
(base) Cered pottes / Sal Peter / vitriole
(base) And diuerse fires / maad of wode and cole
(base) Sal tartre / Alkaly / and Sal preparat /
(base) And combust matires / and coagulat
(base) Cley / maad withhors / and mannes heer and oille
(base) O Tartre / Alum glas / berme / wort and Argoille
(base) Resalgar / and oure matires enbibyng
(base) And eek of oure matires encorporyng
(base) And of oure siluer citrinacioun
(base) And of oure cementyng and fermentacioun
(base) Oure yngottes / testes / and many mo
(base) I wol yow telle / as was me taught also
(base) The seuene spirites / and the bodies seuene
(base) By ordre / as ofte I herde my lord hem neuene
(base) ¶ The firste spirit quyk siluer called is
(base) The seconde Orpyment the thridde ywis
(base) Sal Armonyak / and the ferthe Brymstoon
(base) The bodyes seuene eek / . lo hem heere anoon
(base) ¶ Sol gold is / and Luna / siluer we threpe
(base) Mars Iren / Mercurie quyk siluer we clepe
(base) Saturn9 leed / and Iuppiter is tyn
(base) And Venus Coper by my fader kyn
(base) ¶ This cursed craft who so wole excercise
(base) He shal no good han / that hym may suffise
(base) For al the good / he spendeth ther aboute
(base) He lese shal / ther of haue I no doute
(base) Who that listeth / outen his folie
(base) Lat hym come forth / and lerne multiplie
(base) And euery man / that oght hath in his cofre
(base) Lat hym appiere / and wexe a Philosophre
(base) Ascauns / that craft is so light to leere
(base) Nay nay god woot al be he Monk or frere
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Preest or Chanoun / or any oother wyght
(base) Though he sitte at his book bothe day and nyght
(base) In lernyng of this Eluysshe nyce loore
(base) Al is in veyn / and parde muchel moore
(base) To lerne a lewed man this subtiltee
(base) Fy spek nat ther of / for it wol nat bee
(base) And konne he lettrure / or konne he noon
(base) As in effect . he shal fynde it al oon
(base) For bothe / two / by my sauacioun
(base) Concluden in multiplicacioun
(base) Ylike wel / whan they han al ydo
(base) This is to seyn / they faillen bothe two
(base) Yet / forgat I / to maken rehersaille
(base) Of watres corosif / and of lymaille
(base) And of bodies mollificacioun
(base) And also / of hir induracioun
(base) Oilles / Ablucions / and metal fusible
(base) To tellen al / wolde passen any Bible
(base) That owher is / wherfore as for the beste
(base) Of alle thise names / now wol I me reste
(base) For as I trowe / I haue yow toold ynowe
(base) To reyse a feend / al looke he neuer so rowe
(base) ¶ A nay lat be / the Philosophres stoon
(base) Elixer clept . / we sechen faste echoon
(base) For hadde we hym / thanne were it siker ynow
(base) But vn to god of heuene / I make avow
(base) For al oure craft whan we han al ydo
(base) With al oure sleighte / he wol nat come vs to
(base) He hath maad vs spenden muchel good
(base) For sorwe of which / almoost we wexen wood
(base) But that good hope / crepeth in oure herte
(base) Supposynge / though we sore smerte
(base) To be releeued / by hym afterward
(base) Swich supposyng and hope / is sharp and hard
(base) I warne yow wel / it is to seken euere
(base) That futur temps / hath maad men disseuere
(base) In trust ther of / from al that euere they hadde
(base) Yet of that Art they kan nat wexen sadde
(base) For vn to hem / it is a bitter sweete
(base) So semeth it for nadde they but a sheete
(base) Which that / they myghte wrappe hem Inne at nyght
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And a brat to walken Inne by day lyght
(base) They wolde hem selle / and spenden on the craft
(base) They kan nat stynte / til no thyng be laft
(base) And eueremoore / where that euere they goon
(base) Men may hem knowe / by smel of Brymstoon
(base) For al the world / they stynken as a goot
(base) Hir sauour is so rammyssh and so hoot
(base) That though a man / a Mile from hem be
(base) The sauour wole infecte hym truste me
(base) And thus by smel / and threedbare array

div.l: (base) And that as swithe / preeued it shal bee

div.l: (base) Which that I haue / or elles wexe I wood

(base) So ferforth / that vnnethe is ther noon

div.l: (base) If that youre eyen / kan nat seen aright

(base) Medleth namoore / with that Art I mene

(base) ¶ Also / ther was a disciple of Plato

(base) ¶ Which is that quod he ; Magnasia is the same

div.l: (base) ¶ It is a water / that is maad I seye

div.l: (base) Se how he nappeth se how for Cokkes bones

div.l: (base) Ther was gret showuyng bothe to and fro

div.l: (base) And seyde I se wel it is necessarie

(base) Of that matere ye gete namoore for me
(base) Telle on thy Manciple I the preye
(base) Wel sir quod he now herkneth what I seye
(base) Explicit prophemiun
(base) Narrat
(base) Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adoun

div.l: (base) Of Phitoun so as telleth vs the storie

div.l: (base) Yet hath this bryd by twenty thousand fold

div.l: (base) If men shal telle proprely a thyng

(base) Bitwix a wyf that is of heigh degree

(base) And to the Crowe o false theef seyde he
